loans.name: Seepa

texts.en: Fifty-eight year old Seepa T. weaves mats and other household items in the traditional Samoan method.  Seepa does some weaving herself but her main source of income is preparing the material used for weaving and selling this to other traditional Samoan weavers.  Seepa is pictured here in front of the laupaono plant.  This native plant has strong leaves that are cut, stripped of their thorns and dried.  These dried leaves form the basic material used for weaving Samoan mats and other goods.  She is seeking a loan so that she can acquire the knives and other tools she needs to keep preparing the leaves and supplying them to Samoan weavers.

loans.use: to buy a set of knives and other tools to prepare laupaono leaves for weaving and selling

loans.name: Seira

texts.en: Thirty-five-year-old Seira P. is a mother of two.  Her husband works a small farm.  However, to pay the household bills and the children’s education expenses, Seira must work, too.  Through her talent in weaving and crafting traditional Samoan handbags, she can contribute meaningfully to the family finances.  A loan will help Seira purchase the raw materials that she needs to make these woven bags.  She would use the loan to buy laupaono leaves (the leaves of a native Samoan plant used for weaving), fabric, glue sticks, knives, and needles.  Seira's handbags are sold at flea markets, and the buyers are both locals and tourists.

loans.use: Buy laupaono leaves, fabric materials, glue sticks, knives and needles

loans.name: Siavii

texts.en: Gathering coconuts is not an easy or safe job.  But for Siavii, it is a way to ensure that she can fund the education of her children.  She is thirty-six years old, and she is able to run her business gathering and selling coconuts with continuous help from her four children.  Her husband works at one of the supermarkets in the capital, but his income is not enough to support their large family.  So Siavii has requested a loan to invest in some tools that will help make her work more productive, hopefully enabling her to increase her sales.

loans.use: Machetes and other tools

loans.name: Leaso

texts.en: Leaso has six children who are attending primary school. She chose sewing as her business because she is skillful in doing it and she learned it from her mother. She started with a $750 loan and it was used to buy her brand new electronic sewing machine to replace her old one. She's the one who sewed the National Bank of Samoa's uniform. She also sews different items of clothing and takes them to the flea market in town to be sold. She enjoys doing her business because she believes it is very helpful in supporting her family, especially the raising of her six young kids. Leaso is looking forward to another loan to buy more materials so her customers' supplies aren't limited.

loans.use: To purchase more material, thread, and needles

loans.name: Simamao

texts.en: 30-year old Simamao comes from the small Samoan village of Saleilua.  She is married and has two children.  However, her husband is unemployed, making Simamao the breadwinner of the family.  She runs a small store in her village.  When fully stocked, Simamao can bring in a handsome profit, as the next general store is a mile away.  However, she is currently running low on inventory, and she is desperate for a loan to finance her next inventory purchase to ensure she can maintain a consistent supply for her local customers.  Her goal is to keep her customers satisfied and loyal.

loans.use: Buy merchandise and food for re-sale

loans.name: Losivale Palepa

texts.en: Even though Losivale is getting old, she is still an active and hard working woman with 11 children. She started with a $750 loan to start her business of sewing and also printing materials. She used that loan to buy material, paints, thread and a brand new sewing machine to replace her old machine. She's interested in doing this business because she's very good at it, plus this is the business which helps her most with her children's education and food expenses. So, she is planning to get another loan with the hope of building a special house in which to operate and sell her finished goods.

loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Tagivale

texts.en: For banana plantation owner Tagivale M., her family of six is her main priority.  She does whatever it takes to provide for this large family.   When she heard about the SPBD loan program, she joined immediately, seeing a means of growing her business.  She purchased a stall at the local flea market to sell the bananas from her small plantation.  Now, Tagivale wants to improve her plantation, and having repaid her initial loan, she is anxious to invest in some fertilizers and pest control products so that she can enhance her crop yield.

loans.use: Buy pest control products and fertilizer

loans.name: Lusia

texts.en: Lusia used her first loan to purchase materials and equipments to operate her elei business. Realising that what she earned wasn't enough to cover both the business and family expenses, she looked for other ways to improve her business. She is married with two children; one of them is in school. She is delivering her elei materials to different shops in town and also to church youths who need elei styles for their uniforms. She is now paying back her 2nd loan of $750, which was used to buy more elei woods with different designs. She is aiming to extend her home to add another room for storage of valuable items.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for home extension

loans.name: Tauloto

texts.en: Making beautiful Samoan handicrafts begins with knowledge of the land and the people, and that is what attracts so many to the beautiful art of traditional Samoan crafts.  Tauloto is a 26-year old single mother.  Financial self-sufficiency is a daily struggle for Tauloto, and her flea market stall is her only means to achieve this goal.  She stocks the stall that she rents at the local flea market with traditional Samoan handicrafts made by her and others in her village.  She is seeking a loan in order to pay flea market rents and purchase some tools to aid her in making crafts to sell at her stall.

loans.use: Purchase tools and pay flea market rents

loans.name: Maggie

texts.en: After finishing school, Maggie, 23, decided to set up a business to earn a living rather than look for a job.  She bakes pancakes, pork buns and German buns which she sells in her flea market stall in Apia's town centre. She has developed a good number of loyal customers  not only because of the quality of her products but also because of her good customer relations.  When she joined the SPBD microfinance program her first loan was used to set up her thriving business.  Her earnings enabled her to help her mother and her siblings.  She has also consistently set aside some savings for her future needs. She is a very young lady of twenty-three years of age. For this loan she is planning to replace her old oven with a bigger and new one to respond to increased demand for her products.

loans.use: Purchase new gas oven and additional baking ingredients

loans.name: Tooa

texts.en: Tooa, 37, lives with her extended family in a small seaside village in Samoa.  Prior to joining the SPBD program, she operated a small business comprised of four beach fales on a white sand beach.  (Fales are small, open huts with thatched roofs built in the style of the traditional Samoan house.)  Tooa has used a previous loan to expand her fales.  However, Tooa believes that in order to compete in this tourist market, she will need to renovate her fales and add more guest services.  Thus, she is applying for an additional loan and hoping with this reinvestment she can attract more backpackers and tourists to her beach fales.

loans.use: Build additional beach fales

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is married with one daughter. She is very good at making bakery products such as cakes, pies, midpies and pork buns. She delivers her products to one of the big shops in Apia's town centre. When she got her first loan from SPBD, she was able to produce more products and deliver these to different shops in her village aside from her usual shop in town. She is planning to get another loan to buy a new good oven for her baking and build a small special house for the business only. Because of her growing bakery business  she is now able to build up some savings for renovating her house in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a new oven and build a separate house for her business

loans.name: Vaelupemaua

texts.en: For shop owner Vaelupemaua T., being the family breadwinner is not easy when there is a large family and many disputes.  Although her immediate and extended family tends a small plantation, her shop is this large family's main source of income.  Maintaining this lucrative business is a lot of responsibility.  Currently, Vaelupemaua is running low on inventory.  Given her family's needs, she is not always able to reinvest as much of the profit as she would like back into the business.  So she is currently applying for a loan to purchase inventory and re-stock her shop.  This will ensure she is able to keep her doors open and her loyal customers returning.

loans.use: Re-stock her shop

loans.name: Merita

texts.en: Merita is already 73 but she is still a very active businesswoman.  When she joined the SPBD microfinance program she borrowed a small amount to start her sewing business at home.  Despite her age, the quality of her sewing has attracted a growing number of customers. Gradually she was able to grow her sewing business and is now contemplating expanding her house so that she can have a separate shop room for her sewing business.

loans.use: To expand her shop and purchase additional fabrics for her sewing business

loans.name: Vaituutuus

texts.en: Vaituutuus runs a small shop in the small Samoan village where she was born and raised.  Vaituutuus is married and has two children.  Her husband moved to New Zealand to try to work and support his family in Samoa.  However, the intermittent income he sends home is not enough to support the family.  The sales in Vaituutuus' shop are necessary to provide for the family's basic necessities.  Vaituutuus is passionate about ensuring her children have a future full of opportunities.  She joined SPBD in order to gain access to capital to help her grow her shop and expand her product line.  She expects that being able to offer a larger variety of products will help enlarge her customer base and boost her sales.

loans.use: Expand product line

loans.name: Natia

texts.en: Natia is married with two children.  She started  her small grocery business from a small loan she got from joining the SPBD microfinance program.  Now on her third loan cycle, she intends to further expand her business by purchasing additional stocks.  She intends to set up a Elei  printing -- a traditional Samoan way of handprinting textiles -- business in the future using the additional earnings she will get from her business. She believes that with two businesses, in the future she will be able to significantly contribute to her household income.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks for her grocery shop

loans.name: Aifili

texts.en: Supporting the family is Aifili's job.  She is twenty-three years old and has three small children.  But her husband is unable to find employment, and so Aifili took it upon herself to find a way to provide for her young family.  She joined the SPBD program to gain access to capital that she could use to launch her small village store.  Having a strong history of repayment in full and on time, Aifili has continued to qualify for subsequent loans that she uses to finance inventory purchases.  She wants to keep expanding her product supply until she has a full-scale grocery store. Being the sole breadwinner is a lot of responsibility for a twenty-three-year-old woman, but she is determined and hardworking and confident in her success.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Nuuuli

texts.en: Nuuuli is married with five children.  Her husband is a very good fisherman while she is the one who sells the catch to the villagers. The husband and wife teamwork proved to be a good business formula.  Now they are planning, with a new loan, to purchase additional fishing gear and a new canoe so that her husband's brother can join in their business.  Nuuli’s business acumen, marketing skills and prudent cash management are her major strengths.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing gear and a new canoe

loans.name: Ofu

texts.en: She is a lady of thirty-two years of age, with six children.  She used to have great difficulty in meeting her family's needs, particularly the education of her children. When she joined the SPBD microfinance program, she decided to start a small  retail store and used a portion of her loan to expand her husband's taro farm.  Her little investment proved to be successful. She was  able to gradually expand her retail store and her husband's farm was also able to earn additional income, which they used to build a separate shed for her retail shop. She is now very excited to get another loan  to expand the inventory of her retail shop. With the two growing businesses she hopes that she will be able to set aside enough savings for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her retail store

loans.name: Eliepa

texts.en: Eliepa is a 69-year-old woman living in a small Samoan village.  She has a small pension entitlement from the government, but this isn't enough to live on or to help her build up her savings account balance.  So Eliepa runs a flea market stall.  She started just selling peanuts, but she has now expanded into merchandise, including women's and men's clothing.  Eliepa is a rarity in Samoan society – a woman of nearly 70 years who is financially independent.  She is quick to report that she doesn't believe that age is limiting – you just need to have passion for what you do, and then you can find the strength to do it.  A loan will ensure that Eliepa can keep her flea market stall fully stocked and continue working daily for her much-prized financial independence.

loans.use: Merchandise for flea market stall

loans.name: Peleiupu

texts.en: Peleuipu is married with two children. The whole family is living together with Peleiupu's parents-in-law, who are very old. Life is hard for them considering that the whole extended family relies on the meagre income of her husband. When she got to know about the SPBD microfinance program, she thought of the idea of starting a small business to help her husband earn a living. Her first loan from SPBD was used to set up a pancakes and chips business. She sold them to the nearby village school. Later on she discovered that there is great demand for her products on Sunday evenings when most of the households are gathered together for family dinners. Her initial success has given her the confidence to expand her new business by buying a bigger stove and additional stock to be used for her pancakes and chips business.

loans.use: To purchase a new stove and additional stock for her business

loans.name: Kuini

texts.en: Kuini makes brooms to sell. In Samoa most people use brooms made from dried coconut leaves. Kuini gathers and buys these dried coconut leaves and works hard to make brooms from them. She makes brooms that people use inside their homes as well as brooms that people use to rake up leaves in their yards. She sells her product at the local market.  She works very hard but is rewarded at the end of every week when she balances the books for her business. She often finds that she has cleared ST 400 (USD 160) in profit. Her husband has a job as a salesperson in town and his wages bring in ST 180 (USD 70) weekly.  With the two incomes, Kuini and her husband can support their family. Kuini is justifiably proud of the entrepreneurial spirit that allows her to bring home an income substantially higher than her husband's.

loans.use: Buy material for making brooms

loans.name: Lagolago

texts.en: Lagolago holds the elected post of chief in her SPBD center. She is a long-time member of the program and provides a good example to the rest of the center members. She has used micro-loan facilities to launch a village store and continues to use these facilities to keep expanding the product line she offers. She has a strong history of repayment on time and in full, and she thus qualifies for a home improvement loan. She will use the funds to help her finish construction of her new home.

loans.use: Home improvement

loans.name: Puapuaga

texts.en: Puapuaga is married with five children. She started her business selling Samoan cocoa and pancakes using a small loan from the SPBD program in 2006. She usually operates her little  business during mornings when people prepare for their breakfast.  Recently, she was able to get a special arrangement with the nearby school to supply pancakes and Samoan cocoa for breakfast. With a more steady market, she is now more confident in expanding her business by purchasing an additional oven, grinder and stocks for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a new oven for the pancakes, grinder for the cocoa, and additional ingredients for the business

loans.name: Laki

texts.en: Laki is a 40-year-old mother of four children. Laki works hard to support her family by selling coconut water (locally referred to as a Niu drink). In Samoa, cracking a coconut and sticking a straw in it to drink the water is a favorite refreshment. Laki buys fresh coconuts from local villagers, and then she transports the coconut supply across the Samoan countryside to sell to hotels and in the larger Samoan markets. Laki is anxious to continue to offer the best service possible and ensure a consistent supply, so she is applying for a small loan to help her do this. Laki knows that with the South Pacific Games coming to Samoa later in the year, coconuts at hotels and markets will be in even larger demand.  So she is anxious to keep investing in her business so that she can meet this large demand later in the year.

loans.use: Financing for purchasing coconut inventory

loans.name: Rina

texts.en: Rina is married with three children. She wasn't able to finish school and had difficulty finding a job. Fortunately, her parents gave their existing retail shop to Rina for her to continue because they were too old to run it themselves. She joined the SPBD microfinance program so that she could get a loan to improve the retail shop her parents gave her. She is very much excited to purchase a freezer so that she can sell frozen food and ice cream and, of course, purchase more stock to make her retail shop more attractive to customers.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer and additional stock for her retail shop

loans.name: Sauleone

texts.en: Sauleone is a mother of five children. Her husband's meager income is enough to meet their daily needs but there is practically nothing left for her children's education.  This prompted Sauleone to join the SPBD microfinance program so that she could start a business of her own. Her first small loan was used to start her popcorn business. It surprised her that she was able to sell a lot of popcorn in her village school. She used her second loan to pay her children's school fees, confident that she could pay back her loan from the earnings of her popcorn business. Now, she is planning to expand her popcorn business by buying more stock and a bigger stove and cooking equipment so that she can start supplying the different food stalls in the Apia town market with her tasty popcorn.

loans.use: To purchase a stove and cooking utensils and additional stock

loans.name: Leama

texts.en: Leama sells fagusea (seafood) and faiaipusi (eel in coconut cream). In this picture, she is shown with some of her fish for sale. The fish is wrapped (sometimes with coconut cream) in leaves of native plants and baked over hot stones. Through these sales, she can earn up to ST 160 on a good day (about USD 65). Although these are good revenues, she finds that with six children, her weekly income only just covers her weekly expenses. However, Leama is not ready to give up. She believes that growing her business is the only way that she will be able to improve her family's standard of living and be able to start a savings account. Leama will use a loan to purchase more ingredients that will enable her to expand the supply she brings to the market each day.

loans.use: Buy food supplies

loans.name: Scholastica

texts.en: Scholastica has eight children. She has been doing sewing to eke out a living for her family. Her husband has no job. She recently joined the SPBD microfinance program with the hope that she can buy a new sewing machine (to replace her old one) and purchase additional clothing material so she can earn more from her sewing business. With her determination and hard work she intends to grow her sewing business if given the opportunity to improve what she has now.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine and clothing material

loans.name: Lesina

texts.en: In Samoa, it is common to see people sitting in front of a large supermarket and selling their home-grown produce. These homemade goods are usually not available in the supermarkets. This is how Lesina sells her product, Samoan cocoa. Cocoa plants grow around her house and she harvests the plants, roasts the beans over hot stones and grinds them to make Samoan cocoa. Samoan cocoa is prized for its unique flavor. Although harvesting, roasting and grinding are hard work, her young children help her in making the final product and selling it to passers-by.

loans.use: Equipment for roasting and grinding cocoa

loans.name: Lilly

texts.en: Cracking open a coconut and sticking a straw in it is a traditional Samoan refreshment. Lilly has a small plot of land with coconut trees. She harvests the coconuts and takes them to the main market and will crack them open for you to drink right away.  In a good week, she can earn up to ST 400 (about USD 150) by selling these coconuts. Lilly says that one of the main benefits of having joined SPBD and using the micro-loan facilities to start up her coconut business is that she has been able to use her profit to fix up her home.

loans.use: Machetes and other tools for harvesting coconuts

loans.name: Malama

texts.en: Malama is twenty-nine years old.  She runs a stall at her village’s local flea market and sells a variety of products.  She caters mostly to local women and sells popular Samoan dresses and a variety of cosmetics and hair accessories.  She is able to clear a weekly profit of about ST 200 (USD 80), and she puts this income towards her children’s education.  Through the stall, she keeps current with their school fees and purchases their uniforms and school supplies.  Her primary aim is always to provide for her children and she views any investment in her business as an investment in their future.  She is applying for a small loan to help expand her product line and hopes this expansion will enable her to make some small improvements to her house.

loans.use: To buy more stuff for her flea market and to improve her home. She is applying for a loan of USD $850.00

loans.name: Mamaia

texts.en: Mamaia lives in a small town in Samoa and operates a stall downtown in her village where she sells an eclectic array of merchandise.  She sells imported clothing popular with teenagers alongside traditional Samoan dresses.  Mamaia is adept at knowing what will sell well in her town and works hard to cater her supply to the tastes and demands of the locals.  She is seeking a small loan in order to finance the purchase of some additional inventories and try out a few different kinds of items in the local market.  She feels her business is a successful one, and with further reinvestment, she thinks she can grow it into a full-fledged retail store.  The local townspeople would also be happy if Mamaia were able to reach this goal.

loans.use: To finance the purchase of some additional inventories for her flea market

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie is married and lives with her husband and five children in a small Samoan village.  Her children are all in school, and paying for their education fees, school uniforms, and school supplies is a drain on the family finances.  In order to ensure that all her children remain in school, Marie runs a fast food stall where she sells cooked foods.  She used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase ingredients for her cooked foods.  Having repaid this initial loan in full and on time, Marie is eligible for a second loan.  She would use this loan to purchase a gas oven that would help her with baking and cooking.  Marie’s dream is to one day own a restaurant.  She says she will keep investing in her food stall and by growing her profits, she can save enough to reach her dream of financing the launch of a restaurant.

loans.use: Gas oven

loans.name: Selau

texts.en: The land is a gift from God, but making it productive it is up to the people to use it - this is what Selau believes.  She is married with one son and is a strong and active young lady.  She started with a small loan from SPBD and used it to buy weed killer and fertilizer for her farm where she grows taro, banana, taamu, yams, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Three days of the week she delivers her farm produce to the market.  Her husband helps her in her farm and they are very happy to work because it gives them more income. They are looking forward to obtaining another loan to buy a second-hand pick up truck for delivering their produce to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand pick up truck for delivery of farm produce to market

loans.name: Merita Seilala

texts.en: Merita is raising four children who are all still in school.  With the motive of keeping them in school and ensuring they have a bright future filled with opportunities, Merita opened a small stall at the local market.  She works hard to make this venture successful.  In her stall she sells baskets and local handicrafts, as well as the popular Samoan dresses, puletasis. She is seeking a small loan to purchase additional merchandise to ensure she will be able to keep a consistent supply of goods. When she keeps her stall fully stocked, she earns ST 100 (about USD 40) a day from her sales; This makes Merita the primary breadwinner in her family and she is anxious to keep investing in her business to increase her income.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for her stall

loans.name: Setima

texts.en: Setima used to work, but was forced to quit her job to look after her four little children. Now that her children are older, Setima realized that in order to augment her husband’s salary, she needed to also earn living. Setima then joined the SPBD microfinance program to start a small retail shop in front of her house. She paid off that loan and now plans to obtain a bigger loan to expand her shop, and also build a billiard game shed near it, as a way of attracting more customers to her store.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her retail shop and purchase a billiard table to start a billiard game business near her store

loans.name: Navy

texts.en: Navy is a 44-year old mother of four children. She sells all different kinds of goods which attract both locals and tourists. Samoan artisans make the merchandise she sells, and her stock ranges from women’s jewelry to hand-printed fabrics to men’s clothing. She works long hours at her stall, which is open six days a week. She can earn up to ST 160 a day (USD 65). This is enough to support the basic needs of her family, but Navy dreams of being able to grow her business and increase her income further. She is seeking loan funds to purchase additional goods from Samoan artisans to re-sell at her stall.

loans.use: Buy goods to resell at flea market

loans.name: Lusia

texts.en: Luisa is a 33-year old woman and married with three small children. Luisa and her husband tend a small taro plantation and the crop is their only source of income.  Luisa works hard on the plantation every day. Developing this land into a sustainable source of income is her way of ensuring that her children can have a good education and a future full of opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase plantation equipment:  knives, wheelbarrow, and fertilizer

loans.name: Sopo

texts.en: Sopo is married with four children.  She and her husband tend a small vegetable patch near their house to earn a living.  She joined the SPBD microfinance program with the hope of improving her vegetable gardening business by purchasing better farming tools, fertilizers, chemicals and more seeds.  She believes that by improving the production of her farm she will be able to sell at least three days a week in the market.  She is confident that with a little loan she can improve their farm and their lives as well.

loans.use: To purchase farm implements, fertilizers, and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Pupa

texts.en: Cracking a coconut and sticking a straw in it to drink the coconut water is a favorite refreshment in Samoa.  Pupa and her husband harvest coconuts and sell them cracked and ready for drinking.  They set up a small stand by the road in their village and sell them to passers-by during the heat of the day.  They sell small drinking coconuts for ST 1 (USD 0.40) and large drinking coconuts for ST 2 (USD 0.80).  They have to sell a lot of coconuts to make enough money to live on and support their small child.  Pupa is thus applying for a loan to purchase some basic tools that will enable them to harvest more coconuts more quickly.

loans.use: Buy machetes and tools for harvesting and cracking coconuts

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika is 34 years old and the mother of six children. Monika’s husband has a steady income from his job as a night watchman in a local hotel, however, Monika felt she should share equally in the financial management of their large family and subsequently joined SPBD; she now runs a small taro and fruit plantation and sells her products at a small stand to local villagers. Monika dreams of being able to save enough to build a proper house for her children and admits to being ashamed of her small, open Samoan house. Monika readily praises the financial support she received from the micro-loan programs and believes with further reinvestment in her business and hard work, she can reach her dreams. In the meantime, she will use part of her requested loan funds to make some much-needed repairs to the roof of her home.

loans.use: Buy fertilizers, weed killers and perform home improvements

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en: At twenty nine years old, Susitina is just starting her family.  She has a one year old daughter and a husband who works part-time as a taxi driver.  Besides having good baking skills, she recently started an elei printing business (a traditional Samoan way of printing fabrics) using a small loan from the SPBD microfinance program. Her business is steadily growing and she is planning to expand it by purchasing more textiles and additional stencils to increase the variety of her designs. She is looking forward to a time when she becomes really successful with her elei printing business so she can also invest in her other passion – baking.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials (stencils, paint, glitters) for her elei printing business

loans.name: Salote

texts.en: Salote earns her living by catching fresh sea urchins, bottling them, then selling them in her local market. She used a previous micro-loan to start up this business and now fetches up to ST 80 a day (about USD 32).  Having repaid her initial loan on time and in full, she is now eligible for a home improvement loan.  She is anxious to secure these funds to make some basic upgrades to her small, open house.

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Orepa

texts.en: Orepa is a 38-year old single mother with two children.  Her husband lives overseas and failed to support her and her children as promised.  She was left to struggle on her own to support her children.  She joined the SPBD program to find a means to provide for her family.  In Samoa, women and men wear bright patterned fabrics, and Orepa had the idea to start a tye-dye business where she makes beautifully patterned fabrics (worn sarong-style by women and men) for both locals and tourists.  With the income from her business, she is able to provide the basic necessities for her children and keep current with their school fees.  Orepa is very proud of herself (as is SPBD) for being a dedicated single mother and a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: Purchase extra goods for upcoming events

loans.name: Tafilisaunoa

texts.en: Tafilisaunoa’s life changed when she attended a women’s committee seminar held in their village three years ago. The seminar encouraged her to learn new skills like sewing, printing, weaving and designing so that she could be productive even if she stayed at home to raise her daughter. At 34 years old, she discovered she had a talent in sewing. She then joined the SBPD Microfinance program in order to buy a second-hand sewing machine to pursue her newly-found skills. It proved to be a wise move and now she is earning enough to help her husband meet their household needs. Tafilisaunoa is now planning to purchase additional clothing materials to meet the increasing demand for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing materials for her expanding sewing business

loans.name: Orepa

texts.en: Orepa is a married, thirty-four year old mother of four sons who is a good baker and who runs a muffin business. Orepa learned baking skills at school and although she never thought of baking as her talent, she baked muffins for her son’s school. There, Orepa heard the kids talking about her muffins and asking her son to make her bake some more for them. Orepa then joined SPBD for financial support to start her business.  She now bakes muffins not only forhe son's school but also for village people. With her requested loan, Orepa will build another extra oven to increase her daily production.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for her muffins and cement for making a new oven.

loans.name: Taulagia

texts.en: Taulagia is married and has ten children.  She and her husband have struggled to support this large family.  Since she joined the SPBD program several years ago and gained access to micro-loan facilities, things have been better.  She has been able to borrow to invest in her family’s plantation, where they raise taro, taamu, yams and bananas.  With another loan she was able to start a taxi business.  Between the plantation and the taxi business, she can provide the basic necessities for her large family.  Taulagia continues to have dreams of a better life and is willing to work hard to achieve them.  She has repaid all of her previous loans in full, and now is applying for an additional loan to buy a second-hand pick-up truck that she can use to deliver her plantation goods to the local market.

loans.use: Buy pickup truck and tools

loans.name: Perenise

texts.en: Perenise is 27 years old and has four children.  She lives with her children and extended family in a small seaside village.  She is bright and happy and full of life.  In her village, she is known as the mermaid because she is in the sea from sun-up to sundown.  She fishes with only a spear in the traditional way that she learned from her grandfather.  She is applying for a small loan from SPBD, and with her requested loan, she is planning to buy some fishing gear and nets.  She will use both methods to get the best yield possible.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and gear

payments.comment: SPBD is pleased to report that Perenise was successfully able to repay her loan ahead of the repayment schedule.  She is now applying for her 2nd loan through SPBD.  She was able to earn a weekly net cash flow of approximately 300 Tala (~120 USD).  Now that she is on to her 2nd loan, part of the loan will be used to pay for repairs to her home and her children's education fees.  Thank you for all your support, Kiva Lenders!

loans.name: Seeti

texts.en: Seeti is a 67-year old widow and works hard to remain financially independent.  While it is rare for a senior woman to work for a living and have independent financial security, Seeti does it via her weaving business.  Seeti weaves in the traditional Samoan way.  Women weavers are less common today than when Seeti was young, but there remains high demand for her fine mats.  People place orders with Seeti for special occasions, such as weddings and funerals.  She can earn up to ST 400 (about USD 160) per week with her mat sales.  Seeti is passionate about remaining independent and not relying on her children for financial support, and loan funds will help her do this.  Micro-loan facilities have ensured that Seeti can continue to purchase enough raw materials to fill her orders in a timely manner.

loans.use: Buy weaving materials

loans.name: Siapu

texts.en: Siapu M. is a widow with six children and two grandchildren.  Since her husband’s passing, she has found it difficult to care for her family financially from her taro plantation which is her only source of income.  She has used micro-loan facilities to keep investing in her plantation and ensure that this income source remains viable.  She is currently seeking loan funds to purchase weed killers, insecticides and fertilizers to improve her crop yield and thus enhance her income.

loans.use: To buy weed killers, insecticides and fertilizers

loans.name: Tausaga

texts.en: Tausaga has been married only a few months, but neither she nor her husband have ever had steady employment.  Tausaga used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase seed and supplies to plant a vegetable and fruit garden.  She has been raising cabbages, cucumbers, peas, tomatoes and pineapples.  She hopes to grow this small farm into a reliable income stream. Tausaga has her first loan in full and on time, She is now eligible for a home improvement loan.  Tausaga lives with her husband in a small, open Samoan house.  She is very anxious to build a proper house for her future children.

loans.use: Build house for her family

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en: Susitina and her husband run a small store in the Samoan village of Tapatapao.  This is their only source of income, and they are able to bring in about ST 250 (about USD 100) a week to meet their financial needs.  Susitina is confident that she can grow the store to a larger scale, but she will need to purchase additional goods for her store.  Because repaid her initial loan in full and on time, Susitina qualifies for additional funds, and with this loan, she should be able to get closer to her dream of being a successful proprietor of a large retail store.

loans.use: Re-stock the shop

loans.name: Sii

texts.en: Sii M. is a 40-year old single mother.  Her biological son is grown, but she has adopted three additional children from relatives who had no means to support them.  Sii works very hard running a small taro plantation to support all of her children.  She sells her produce to area hotels.  Her kindness has helped her to build a good relationship with her customers, and she is very focused on keeping them them satisfied.  Her main goal is to provide for her children, and she is passionate about providing them all a good education and future full of opportunities.

loans.use: To buy chain link fence, timbers and tools

loans.name: Tauva

texts.en: Tauva is a single woman who works hard to contribute to her family’s income.  She spends most of her time making clothing and decorative handicrafts for re-sale at the local flea market.  After all expenses, she can clear about ST 140 a week (about USD 55), and of this income, some goes to savings and the rest she willingly gives to her parents and siblings to help make small improvements in the family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Buy materials for making handicrafts

loans.name: Tiresa

texts.en: Tiresa is a widow with six children.  When her husband passed away, she was left without steady income.  Supporting this large family on her own is very difficult.    Tiresa learned to sew and how to make hand-printed fabrics from her mother.  Tiresa is leveraging her talent as a seamstress to achieve her dream of financial security.  She prints fabrics and sews clothes to order for the local villagers.  However, she is anxious to expand her business and build up a stock of finished fabrics and clothing for larger scale retail sale.  Tiresa feels this is the only way to earn enough to ensure that her children can stay in school and have a bright future.

loans.use: Buy material and fabric-printing tools

loans.name: Telematina

texts.en: Telematina makes and sells traditional Samoan handicrafts.  She crafts kava bowls, war knives and traditional women’s wear.  She also sells jewelry and decorative items made from coconut shells.  She keeps her flea market stall open every single day, and she is rewarded by being able to bring in up to ST 120 (USD 50) a day.  After paying all of her large family’s expenses, she tries to save every week to provide her family a cushion for future hard times.

loans.use: Raw materials for making handicrafts and women's clothing

loans.name: Sose

texts.en: Sose is applying for her first loan.  Neither she nor her husband have a job, and they rely on their small taro plantation for survival.  Sose realizes that they need to invest in the plantation and increase the output of the plantation if they are going to be able to support their children.  They live in a very small village, and their four boys attend the local village school, and it is the income from their taro crop that is paying for their school fees.  Sose is a firm believer in hard work, and she thinks with a loan they can purchase some basic tools and fertilizer to do some more planting and grow their crop.  Any extra income they can bring in would have a direct and noticeable impact on the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Expand taro plantation

loans.name: Vailaau

texts.en: Vailaau, 19, is married and has three children.  She wasn’t able to finish school and was unable to find a job.  She has attended some Women’s Committee seminars in her local village where local women teach other women how to sew, weave, design and make traditional Samoan crafts in order to allow a woman a means of supporting herself.  This is where Vailaau learned how to make the crafts that she now makes and is able to sell to bring in some income.  She has been using micro-loan facilities from SPBD in order to purchase raw materials for her crafts, which she re-sells at flea markets to locals and tourists.  Now having repaid in full four previous business loans, Vailaau is eligible for a home improvement and education loan.  She will use this loan to repair the damaged roof of her house, and to pay for her children’s school fees and uniforms.  Vailaau is confident that she can repay this loan (as she has all others) with the income from her crafts business.

loans.use: Home improvement and education fees

loans.name: Suafai

texts.en: Suafai is a mother of ten children, seven of whom she has adopted from relatives.  She struggles hard to provide for this large family.  One of the innovative ways that she has found to bring in money is buy operating a coconut and taro exchange.  She stocks some basic goods and when people in her local village do not have the money to buy them, she exchanges the goods for taro and coconuts.  She then sells the coconuts to the Coconut Oil Factory and the taro at the local food market.  Operating this exchange, Sufai is able to clear a profit most weeks of USD 120.  Sufai is confident that she can continue to grow this business and aims to someday open a small shop of her own.

loans.use: Purchase basic goods to exchange for coconuts and taro

loans.name: Tomumu

texts.en: Tomumu is 40 years old.  She enjoys fishing, and it is her livelihood.  She sells her daily catch at the roadside of her village and sometimes walks to a neighboring village to sell it.  She is applying for a small loan to buy some new nets and fishing gear for her small business.  Tomumu feels that her fishing is the only way for her to secure a bright future, and so she is anxious to keep growing it until she can save enough to buy a motorboat to go further out to sea and get a better catch.

loans.use: Buy new nets and fishing gear

loans.name: Talatupu

texts.en: Talatupu is 40 years old, married and has 6 children. Talatupu uses two means to support herself and her family.  She runs a taro plantation and sells her crop at the local markets.  Additionally, she weaves mats and sells these mats to locals who use them in their home.  As the country of Samoa develops, there are many modernizing influences on society and many feel that their traditional culture is fading.  But it is people like Talatupu who keep the knowledge and practice of the traditional crafts alive.  In her village she is known for teaching young girls how to weave and feels it is important that women continue to pass on this practice through the future generations.  Talatupu has used a previous micro-loan to purchase tools that make her weaving faster and different objects that she can use to decorate the mats.  She is known for her original designs.  Talatupu is seeking additional loan funds to buy tools for both weaving mats and farming her taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy tools for both weaving and farming

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en: Tamara has been a member of SPBD for a year and a half.  She resides in a small Samoan village with her extended family.  Tamara is the dependable caretaker of the family plantation.  With the help of her nieces and nephews living in the village, she is able to keep up with the hard farm work.  Having used (and fully repaid) previous loans to invest in her land and improve her taro crop, she is now seeking funds to purchase new tires for the truck she uses to haul her crop to the market every week.  Without the ability to transport her crop, she can’t turn her crop into the income that her family relies on.

loans.use: Repair crop transportation

loans.name: Tausaga

texts.en: Tausaga is 43 years old.  She has eleven children.  It is the income from her and her husband’s cattle farm that has provided for all of these children.  Tausaga has to work daily to tend her cattle and her children; both are hard work.  She is applying for a loan to purchase new gates for their pastures.  Tausaga is passionate about being able to provide for her large family, and she feels that keeping their cattle farm productive and in good condition is the key to ensuring her children have a bright future.

loans.use: Buy new pasture gates

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia is a 40-year old woman living in a small Samoan village.  She has three grown children who all have employment at a resort in ther village.  Telesia recounts many incidents of hardship – her husband’s unsteady income, health crises – but feels that all of these episodes have served to strengthen her character and her resolve to succeed.  She has run a sustainable business for some years now, selling ice-pops and cut flower arrangements.  She is especially keen to retain her main customer to whom she sells flowers.  Telesia will use loan funds to purchase bulk ingredients for making ice-pops and purchasing some basic gardening tools to make her time in her flower gardens more productive.

loans.use: To purchse bulk ingredients for making ice-pops and flower gardening tools

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia S. lives in a small Samoan village with her husband and two children.  Her husband is unemployed, and her family faced a lot of financial problems prior to Telesia joining SPBD.  But Telesia decided to join the program and leverage her sewing talent to launch a proper business.   Her business is now six years old, and the income from it supports her family.  She is seeking additional loan funds to purchase materials to keep a consistent supply of clothing available to her customers.  Telesia is a talented seamstress, and she is also an adept businesswoman.  She enjoys exploring new ways to make her customers happy with original material and patterns.

loans.use: Buy material

loans.name: Tusiga

texts.en: Tusiga lives in a small Samoan village with her husband.  Her five children live with her sister in Samoa’s capital because there are better schools there.  Tusiaga works hard to be able to fund her children’s education through her taro sales.  However, there have been many incidents of her crop having been reduced by theft or by wild animals digging it up.  To protect her valuable income (and children’s education funds), Tusiga is seeking loan funds to purchase a barrier fence to enclose her crop.

loans.use: Purchase barrier fence

loans.name: Ulufale

texts.en: Ulufale is 32 years old and is married with five children.  Her husband passed away two years ago, leaving her alone to raise and support her children.  Ulufale fell very ill after her husband’s passing, and she was in the hospital for three months.  Her children dropped out of school and began working on the taro plantation.  When Ulufale was well enough to leave the hospital, she found so much joy and hope in her children’s strength and she vowed to go on with her life and put the past firmly behind her.  Her resolve to gain financial security was strengthened by this experience, and she now works on her plantation daily and is taking out a loan to purchase some fertilizer and to pay the school fees necessary to get her children back in school.  Her hope is that she can save enough money to take her family overseas, as she wants to ensure that her children have lives full of opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for taro plantation and children’s school fees

loans.name: Vii

texts.en: Most people wouldn’t enjoy waking up every single morning to face a day of work in their field.  But that is seventy-one year old Vii’s life, and she loves it.  Although her husband passed away, her ten children remain near her and help her tend the plantation.  Vii is also a breast cancer survivor.  She was diagnosed with the disease in 2003, but today, she remains active and strong.  Shortly after her bout with cancer, Vii joined the SPBD program to gain access to the capital needed to keep reinvesting in her only income source, her taro plantation.  She has used past loan funds to purchase fertilizer, fencing and various tools.  She is seeking additional loan funds for the same purpose.

loans.use: Buy weed killer and fertilizer

loans.name: Leitu

texts.en: Leitu lives in a small Samoan village with her husband and newborn baby.  Her husband works as a carpenter and earns just enough to provide for the basic necessities for their family of three.  Leitu’s parents recently passed away, and left her their small taro plantation.  Leitu capitalized on this opportunity to earn additional income.  She joined SPBD to gain access to the capital necessary for her to develop her land into a productive taro farm.  She is requesting loans to purchase fertilizer and some basic tools to help her through her first large harvest seasons

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and basic tools

loans.name: Olovesi

texts.en: Olovesi is a 36-year old mother of three children. She makes flavored ice-pops and sells them in her village.  Due to the tropical climate, these cold treats are very popular with Samoan children.  She used an initial SPBD loan to purchase a freezer for her ice-pops.  Now Olovesi has two goals in seeking additional loan funds.  First, she wants to buy bulk ingredients to try out a new secret recipe to differentiate her ice-pops from the others sold in town.  Second, she wants to try making home-made, fresh-squeezed juices and sell these as well.  A loan will help this enterprising woman differentiate her products and grow her sales.

loans.use: Purchase bulk ingredients for ice-pops

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa is 21 years old and is married with one child.  She grew up with her mother and father labouring on their family plantation to bring in enough income to support their large family.  Now it is Epenesa’s turn to provide for her family, and she is trying to develop her banana plantation to do so.  She wants to cultivate her land so that the banana crop can bring in a steady income for her family’s future.  She brings her crop to her local village market as well as those markets in neighbouring villages for sale.  She is passionate about ensuring that her child has a future full of opportunity, and is thus anxious to reinvest in her land.  She will use loan funds to purchase fertilizer and pest control agents to improve her crop yield.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pest control agents for plantation

loans.name: Miriama

texts.en: Miriama and her husband are very talented, and they decided to leverage these talents to support their family.  With help from an SPBD loan, Miriama was able to launch a real jewelry-making business.  She is asking for additional funds to upgrade the tool set she and her husband use to make their wares.  They make necklaces, earrings, hair combs and bracelets.  Most of their products are made from material native to Samoa – for instance, they make much use of coconut shells in their designs.  Their products are sold in handicraft stalls that cater to tourists and locals alike.

loans.use: To purchase a new tool set for creating jewelry

loans.name: Salaevalu

texts.en: Salaevalu is married with eight children.  In order to support her family, she makes hand-printed fabrics that are sold in local flea market stalls.  Making hand-printed fabrics takes time, patience and precision.  Salaevalu works hard to make her fabrics special, and her designs are artistic and individualized, and so they sell well.  The hand-printed fabrics are bought by seamstresses to make clothing or else are bought to be worn as sarongs (locally referred to as “lava lava”) by men and women alike.

loans.use: Purchase fabric

loans.name: Olinda Jaime

texts.en:
Olinda Jaime M. is 35 years old. She was born and raised in Namaacha, a Maputo province. She was raised by her parents until she was 11 years old. Olinda attended elementary school until the 3rd grade, when she had to leave her parents home to live with relatives in Matutuíne district. Olinda did not have the opportunity to continue her studies because due to the civil war of 1984, she and her relatives had to move to the district of Boane. In 1987, Olinda married and had 10 children, of which 4 passed away. Since 1999, she has been engaged in the goat sales business. In 2007 she was introduced to HLUVUKU-ADSEMA by friends. There she learned about the prospects of access to credit. With the loan of 10.500,00 MT, Olinda intends to increase sales volume in order to strengthen her only means of income and sustenance for her family. Olinda’s business has a positive impact in her community because it generates employment for Olinda and provides goat meat to the Boane community.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 5 - Boane Cliente: Olinda Jaime M. Sector De Actividade : Comercialização de Caprinos Valor de Empréstimo: 10.500,00MT (420.00US$) Aplicação de empréstimo: Compra de caprinos Inicio: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2008 Olinda Jaime M. de 35 anos de idade, natural de Namaacha, Província de Maputo, cresceu sob responsabilidade dos seus Pais ate atingir 11 anos. Frequentou o ensino primário ate a 3ª classe e teve que separar-se dos seus Pais para viver com os seus Tios no Distrito de Matutuíne e não teve mais oportunidade de continuar com os estudos. Devido a guerra civil em 1984, tiveram que transferir-se junto com os tios para o Distrito de Boane . Desde do ano de 1987 casou-se maritalmente e tive 10 filhos, dos quais quatro perderam a vida. Desde 1999, vem assumindo na integra a gestão de negocio de venda de caprinos. Nos princípios de 2007 por indicação de amigas teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA tendo se aproxima a esta para informar-se das condições de acesso ao crédito. Com o empréstimo de 10.500,00MT, pretende aumentar o volume de negocio de forma a fortificar cada vez mais a sua única fonte de rendimento que lhe garante o sustento da sua família. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior nas comunidades porque para alem de providenciar emprego para ela própria providencia carne de cabrito para comunidade de Boane.

loans.use: To buy animals

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Rute José

texts.en:
Rute Jose Z. is 40 years old. She was born and raised in Maputo by her parents. She attended elementary school until the 4th grade and began working as an adolescent. She currently runs a small store in her home. With the 15.000.00MT loan, Rute wants to increase her stock so she can respond to the needs from customers and increase her income. With the increased income she will be able to better cope with her family expenses, including the schooling of her 4 sons. Rute’s business has a positive impact in her community in that it provides the important service of making basic products available closer to the community and at accessible prices.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 4 - Boane Cliente: Rute José Z. Sector de actividade: Comercio Valor de empréstimo: 15.000.00MT (600.00US$) Aplicação de montante: compra de produtos da primeira necessidade Inicio: 10/04/07 Fim: 31/03/2008 Rute Jose Z., de 40 anos de idade, natural de Maputo, cresceu sob responsabilidade dos pais e por falta de interesse por parte dela, estudou muito pouco apenas ate quarta classe, começou a pratica de negocio desde adolescente. Actualmente possui um pequeno estabelecimento comercial junto a sua casa. Com o empréstimo de 15.000.00MT pretende aumentar o volume da mercadoria de forma a responder com as exigências dos cliente e incrementar a sua receita para responder as despesas familiares dentre as quais a educação dos 4 filhos. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque providencia um serviço útil de colocar os produtos de primeira necessidade mais próximos do cliente e apreços acessíveis.

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Nalina

texts.en:
Nalina M. is 43 years old. She was born and raised by her parents in Moamba, in the Maputo province. Her family’s financial situation prevented her from attending school. Since 2005, she has been managing the family business and today owns a small commercial establishment. In the end of 2006, she was introduced by neighbors and friends to HLUVUKU- ADSEMA. There she learned about the prospects of access to credit. With the loan of 10.000,00MT, Nalina wants to increase stock in her business. And consequently her income, which is vital in the sustenance of her family and schooling of her 3 daughters. Her business has a positive impact in her community in that it provides employment for Nalina, brings the products closer to the community, especially to the population of the Bairro 1 de Boaque neighborhood.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro 1 - Boane Cliente: Nalina M. Sector de Actividade : Comercio Valor de Empréstimo: 10.000,00 MT (400.00US$) Aplicação de montante: Compra de produtos . Início: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2008 Nalina M., de 43 anos de idade, natural de Moamba, Provincia de Maputo, cresceu sob a responsabilidade dos seus Pais. A situação financeira da família lhe criou poucas oportunidades para estudar. Desde 2005 vem assumindo na integra a gestão de negocio da família e conta hoje com um estabelecimento comercial. Nos finais de 2006 por indicação dos vizinhos e colegas de serviço teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU- ADSEMA, tendo se aproximado e solicitado informações sobre condições de acesso ao crédito. Com o Empréstimo de 10.000,00MT, pretende aumentar o volume do negocio e aumentar a sua renda que é principal fonte para suportar os encargos familiares, incluindo a educação das três filhas. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque alem de providenciar emprego para ela própria, coloca o produto mas perto do cliente, com particular destaque para a população do Bairro1 de Boane.

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Manuel Jose

texts.en:
Manuel Jose M. is 48-years old. He was born and raised by his parents in the province of Maputo. In 1974, he began working in the Agrarian Station in Umbeluze as an assistant carpenter. In 1985 he worked as a technician in the Center of Research and Rural Development in Moamba. Since 1987, he has been working on his own business in a lot in the Umbeluzi River valley. In the beginning of 2007 he was introduced to HLUVUKU-ASDSEMA by friends and neighbors. There he learned about the prospects of access to credit. With the loan of 11.000,00MT, Manuel wants to prepare the land and purchase seeds for planting maize in a 2 hectares area. Manuel’s activities are beneficial to his community in that it provides employment for Manuel and 2 other workers, as well as providing grains for the local market.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização : Bairro 2 - Boane Cliente: Manuel Jose M. Sector de Actividade: Agricultura Valor de Empréstimo: 11.000,00MT (440.00US$) Aplicação do Montante: Compra de ínsumos agrícolas. Inicio: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2008 Manuel Jose M., de 48 anos de idade, natural de Boane, Província de Maputo, cresceu sub a responsabilidade dos Pais ate aos 17 anos. Em 1974 começou a trabalhar Estacão Agrária de Umbeluze) como ajudante de carpintaria. Em 1985 trabalhou técnico do Centro de experimentação e desenvolvimento rural de Moamba. Desde 1987 vem assumindo na integra a gestão do seu negocio e tem um terreno no vale do rio Umbeluzi. No inicio do ano 2007 por indicação de amigos e vizinhos teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ASDSEMA tendo aproximado e solicitado o primeiro empréstimo para ampliar sua área de produção de 1 para 2 ha. Com o empréstimo de 11.000,00MT pretende preparar terreno e compra de sementes para produção de milho numa área de 2 ha. A sua actividade tem impacto positivo porque alem de providenciar emprego para ele próprio e outras duas pessoas, abastece o mercado local com cereais.

loans.use: To buy seeds and land preparation

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Elisa Maria

texts.en:
Elisa Maria Cuna M. is a 38 year old born and raised in Moamba, Maputo province. She was raised by her parents and attended school until the 4th grade. In 1984 she married and had 4 children. In 2002, Elisa and her children were abandoned by her husband. Since 1985 she has been working on her own business of raising chickens. In the end of 2006, she was introduced to HLUVUKU-ADSEMA by her sister and learned about the possibility of access to credit. She supports her family and the schooling of her 3 children through this business. With the loan of 10.500,00 MT Elisa wants to expand her business to respond to the increasing demand for chickens, and to raise her income. Elisa’s activities have a positive impact in her community because not only it provides employment for Elisa and sustenance for her family, but it also provides chicken meat at competitive prices to the local market

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização : Bairro 2 - Boane Cliente: Elisa Maria cuna M. Sector de Actividade: Avicultura Valor de Empréstimo: 10.500,00MT (420.00 US$) Aplicação do Montante: Compra de pintos para engorde. Inicio: 10/04/2007 Fim: 31/03/2008 Elisa Maria Cuna M., de 38 anos de idade, natural de Moamba, Província de Maputo, cresceu sob responsabilidade dos seus Pais. Estudou até 4ª classe. Em 1984 contraiu matrimónio tradicional com o seu marido com o qual tiveram quatro filhos. Em 2002 foi abandonada pelo marido tendo deixado os 4 filhos sob responsabilidade dela. Desde 1985 vem assumindo na integra a gestão do negocio de engorde de pintos. Nos finais do ano de 2006 por indicação da sua irmã teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA, tendo se informado das condições de acesso ao credito. Com os rendimentos do negocio suporta os encargos da família, incluindo as despesas escolares dos seus três filhos. Com o empréstimo de 10.500,00MT pretende aumentar o volume do seu negocio para dar resposta a maior procura do frango que tem se verificado nos últimos tempos e aumentar a sua renda. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque para alem de providenciar emprego a ela própria, coloca o frango mais perto dos clientes a um preço altamente competitivo.

loans.use: To produce chickens

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Alberto Velasco

texts.en:
Alberto, born in Zavala-Inhambane, is 61 years old. He has 9 children of whom 7 are students and 2 are self employed. Alberto worked as a Machinery technician for the Carmoc enterprise in the decades of 1970 and 80’s, and as a driver. In 1984, he decided to live in Catembe. During this period he borrowed money to purchase a sewing machine. He worked and saved paying his debt with no trouble. During his life in Catembe, Alberto worked as a guard and gardener, but his salary was not enough to sustain his family. In 2002, following the flood Alberto decided to make bricks for the construction of a small shop. With the little money he made he set aside money to stock the shop, to buy necessary materials for the family farm, and money for the schooling of his children. With the profits Alberto was able to build an water well , buy a refrigerator and a television. Alberto heard about Hluvuku through friends and knocked on the door of this micro-financing opportunity in Catembe. With the loan of 11.000,00 MTN, Alberto will increase the stock of his shop and his profits. With the profits he hopes he will be able to better provide for his family and support the schooling of his children. In the future, Alberto hopes to buy a cart to facilitate the transport of goods between the city of Maputo and Catembe.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Chali - Catembe Cliente: Alberto Velasco P. Sector De Actividade: Comércio Valor de Empréstimo: 11.000,00MT (440.00US$) Aplicação de empréstimo: Compra produtos de primeira necessidade Início: 12/04/2007 Fim:31/03/2008 Alberto, nascido em Zavala-Inhambane a 61 anos, tem 9 filhos dos quais 7 estudantes e 2 trabalhadores por conta própria. Trabalhou como maquinista na empresa carmoc na década 70 e 80 como motorista estafeta. Então em 1984 decide passar a viver na Catembe e nessa altura comprou por crédito uma máquina de costura singer que lhe ajudava a fazer pequenas costuras e foi poupando algum dinheiro e outro pagou a máquina sem sobressaltos. Assim durante a sua vida na Catembe, este trabalhara como guarda/jardineiro e recebia pouco salário que não chegava para o sustento da família. É quando decide fabricar blocos para iniciar a construção de um pequeno estabelecimento comercial, isto no ano 2000, logo após as cheias. Com o pouco que ganhava repartia algum para compra de produtos para loja e outro para o rancho da família e por as crianças a estudar. Conseguiu com os lucros fazer o poço de água, comprar um congelador, televisor, chapas de zinco, etc. Ouviu falar da Hluvuku através de amigos e vizinhos e bate a porta desta microfinança em Catembe. Com o empréstimo de 11.000,00MTN vai impulsionar a actividade, aumentando de certa maneira o volume de negócio e, mais margem de lucro. Com o rendimento da actividade consegue sustentar a família, incluindo a educação dos filhos. Futuramente almeja comprar uma carrinha para ajudar no transporte de mercadoria da cidade do Maputo à Catembe e melhorar as instalações.

loans.use: To increase stock in his shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Teresa Helena

texts.en:
Teresa is 34 years old. She was born in Maputo and lived with her father. She studied and in her spare time sold bread and braided hair as a way of helping her family. Teresa left school in the 7th grade. She was married in Ressano Garcia, and had 2 daughters. She worked as a maid and helped her husband in the small shop he owned and operated until his death. Teresa decided to restart her life. She began buying products such as: eggs, cooking oil, and beverages in the neighboring South Africa and delivering them to local shops in the city of Maputo. With the profits she bought a small stand shop in Catembe. She stocked the shop and invited her brother to manage the business. In 2004, Teresa moved in with her mother in Catembe and started managing her shop. In 2005, her younger sister told her about Hluvuku-Adsema. This is her first loan. With the loan of 15,000.00 MTN Teresa wants to diversify her stock, and expand her shop. With the profits she wants to be able to better sustain her family, continue the schooling of her children, and have the shop make an impact in society as place of gathering in the weekends. In the future, she wishes to upgrade her stand to a well known grocery shop in Catembe

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro Guachene - Catembe Cliente: Teresa Helena P. Actividade: Comércio Valor empréstimo: 15.000,00MT (600.00US$) Aplicação do empréstimo: Compra e revenda de produtos a retalho Início: 12/04/2007 Fim: 31/12/2008 Teresa, nascida a 34 anos em Maputo, viveu com o pai na Matola onde estudava e nos tempos livres fazia tranças e vendia pães como forma de ajuda no sustento familiar. Deixou de estudar na 7ª classe, altura que se casou maritalmente e passou a viver com seu marido em Ressano Garcia onde tiveram duas filhas. Ela era doméstica e de vez em quando acompanhava os movimentos das vendas no pequeno estabelecimento no qual seu marido era proprietário, onde este, anos mais tarde veio a falecer. Assim, ela decide recomeçar a vida comprando Produtos como:Ovos, Óleo e Bebidas diversas na vizinha África do Sul e entregava-os aos armazenistas na cidade de Maputo, e com os lucros que ia amealhando decide comprar um pequeno estabelecimento comercial barraca na Catembe tendo reabilitado completamente e apetrechada com uma gama de produtos, logo a seguir contratou seu irmão mais novo para gerir o negocio. Em 2004 decide viver com sua mãe em Catembe e toma a gerência da barraca. Em 2005 a irmã mais nova comentara da Hluvuku-Adsema sendo uma Instituição que concede crédito, e esta decide solicitar o primeiro empréstimo. Com o crédito de 15.000,00MTN ela pretende capitalizar seu negócio colocando diversos produtos, reabilitar e ampliar o seu estabelecimento. Com o rendimento do negócio consegue o sustento da família, por as crianças a estudar e tem impacto na sociedade como local de lazer aos fins de semana. A perspectiva futura é modernizar a barraca e transformá-la numa Mercearia de referencia na Catembe.

loans.use: To increase stock in her shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Marculino Augusto

texts.en:
Marculino, was born in 1967 in Manjacaze province in Gaza. Born to farmers, he studied until the 5th grade. When Marculino was 20 years old he moved to the city of Maputo with hopes of finding a job. He worked in the CFM – Rail roads of Mozambique -, and in his spare time he sold cigarettes, and other products in small quantities in order to provide for the 8 people he sustains. Later, he established himself in the market in Catembe where he is still active. Through HLUVUKU he has made 14 loans which enabled him to strengthen and establish his business. With the loan of 12.150,00 MT, Marculino wants to expand his stock in order to respond to the demands of his clients. In the future, he hopes to move his business to a more visible and larger venue where he will be able to better market his products.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Guachene - Catembe Cliente: Marculino Augusto U. Sector De Actividade: Comércio Valor de Empréstimo: 12.150,00MT (486.00US$) Aplicação de empréstimo: Compra de produtos de primeira necessidade Início: 12/04/07 Fim: 31/03/08 Marculino, nascido em 1967 em Manjacaze provincia de Gaza, filho de pais agricultores estudou ate 5ª classe. Aos 20 anos deslocou-se para a cidade de Maputo afim de procurar um emprego. Trabalhou nos CFM - Caminhos de Ferro de Moçambique como eventual e nos tempos livres dedicava-se a vender cigaros e outros produtos em pequenas quantidades o que mais tarde se tornou na actividade que lhe ajuda a ganhar o pão para sustentar 8 pessoas sob sua responsabilidade. Mais tarde veio instalar-se no mercado da Catembe onde até hoje exerce a sua actividade. Atraves de amigos conheceu a HLUVUKU onde recorreu a um total de 14 emprestimos que lhe ajudaram a fortificar seu negócio. Com o emprestimo de 12.150,00mt, pretende comprar mercadorias para reforçar o seu Stock de modo a responder as necessidades dos clientes. Como prespectiva, pretende transferir o seu estabelecimento para um lugar amplo e visível para melhor expor os seus produtos.

loans.use: To increase stock in his shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Roberto Manuel

texts.en:
Roberto was born in 1959 in Catambe, in the city of Maputo. His father was a cook and his mother a maid. When he was 12 years old Roberto started apprenticing carpentry in his uncle’s shop. His skills as a carpenter have been essential for Roberto to earn enough to sustain 6 people in his family. Roberto apprenticed in various shops until he had to interrupted his studies of carpentry to enter the Mandatory Military service, after which he went to work in the mines in South Africa. When he returned, Roberto was successful in the carpentry business, until his shop was flooded in 2000. Facing difficulties, Roberto had to lay off 4 of his employees and received a loan from HLUVUKU to restart his business. Currently he employs 1 full time worker. With the loan of 11.000,00 MT, Roberto plans on buying wood to produce windows, door frames, and other articles according to the demand from customers. In the future, Robert wants to relocate his shop closer to the market in order to better market his services and strengthen his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Guachene - Catembe Cliente: Roberto Manuel C. Sector De Actividade: Transformação - Carpintaria Valor de Empréstimo: 11.000,00MT (440.00US$) Aplicação de empréstimo: Compra de madeira Início: 12/04/07 FIM: 31/03/08 Roberto, nascido em 1959 na Catembe Cidade de Maputo, filho de pai cozinheiro e mãe doméstica. Aos 12 anos já começava a frequentar o oficina do tio que era carpinteiro, onde aprendeu a profissão que até hoje lhe ajuda a ganhar o pão para sustentar 6 pessoas sob sua responsabilidade. Tendo aperfeiçoado a sua arte com outros mestres com que trabalhava, teve que interromper para cumprir o Serviço Militar Obrigatório, donde saiu e foi trabalhar nas minas da Africa do Sul até 1992. Daí regressou e veio retomar a sua actividade que desenvolveu com sucesso até as cheias de 2000 que infelizmente alagaram a sua oficina e perdeu vários bens seus e de clientes. Enfrentado dificuldades dispensou os 4 trabalhadores que tinha e assim recoreu ao emprestimo na HLUVUKU para reactivar sua actividade. Actualmente conta com um trabalhador. Com o emprestimo de 11.000,00mt, pretende comprar madeira que é a sua principal matéria prima para fazer aros de janelas e portas e varios artigos de acordo com as necessidades dos clientes. Como prespectiva, pretende transferir a sua oficina para as proximidades do mercado de modo a publicitar melhor suas obras oque lhe pode permitir fortificar seu negócio e aumentar os postos de trabalho na comunidade.

loans.use: To buy wood

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel M. was born on December 28, 1976 in the city of Maputo. He has always lived with his parents and studied until the 7th grade. In the nineties he decided to start his own business in Hulene-Expresso, in Maputo. Later, he moved to Catembe and continued his business of the buying and reselling of products. In addition to his commercial activities he is also dedicated to raising cattle in the neighboring district of Matutuíne. Manuel learned about Hluvuku from his father and started borrowing in 2004 in order to expand his business. Since then he has been granted 4 loans which have contributed greatly to his business. With the loan of 15.000,00 MTN, Manuel will further expand his business. His business has a positive impact in the community because not only it employs and sustains him and his family, but it also makes basic necessary products available to the community. In the future, Manuel hopes to expand his business to the neighboring Chamissava.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Localização: Bairro da Marrinha - Catembe Cliente: Manuel M. Sector De Actividade: Comércio Valor de Empréstimo: 15.000,00MT (600.00US$) Aplicação de empréstimo: Compra produtos de primeira necessidade Início: 12/04/2007 Fim:31/03/2008 Manuel M., nasceu a 28 de Dezembro de 1976 na Cidade de Maputo, sempre viveu com os pais onde estudou até a 7ª classe. Decide iniciar a actividade de comércio por conta própria na década 90 em Hulene-Expresso cidade de Maputo, onde trabalhara apenas 1 ano. Mais tarde, mudou de residência e fixa-se na Catembe e continua com o négócio de compra e revenda de produtos. Para além da actividade comercial dedica-se também a pecuária onde tem gado bovino em franco crescimento no distrito vizinho de Matutuíne. O seu contacto com o crédito iniciou em 2004, por iniciativa do pai tendo lhe abordado sobre a Hluvuku como forma de dinamizar e fazer crescer sua actividade. Desde então trabalhou com o crédito tendo desembolsado 4 empréstimos e que vieram dar uma nova dinâmica e crescimento do seu negocio. Assim com o crédito de 15.000,00MTN ele pretende aumentar o volume de negócio. A sua actividade tem um impacto positivo na comunidade pois para além de dar uma ocupação a família, uma vez que quem gere o negócio é a esposa, coloca os produtos da 1ª necessidade mais perto da comunidade A perspectiva futura é ampliar suas instalações e expandir seu negocio para o bairro vizinho de Chamissava.

loans.use: To increase stock in his shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Isabel Salomão

texts.en:
Isabel is 31 years old. She was born in the city of Maputo. She was raised by her mother in the neighborhood of Aeroporto where she studied until the 6th grade. Later she lived with an aunt in Manjacaze – a Gaza province, where she worked in agriculture in order to help her family. In 1993, Isabel married and had 4 children.
