loans.use: To increase stock for radio repair and clothing business

loans.name: Nosa

texts.en: A qualified and trained musician who entertains his community and the public with his music, Mr. Nosa E. is 27 years old. He hails from the ancient City of Benin, Edo State, Nigeria. He hopes to get the above amount for business improvement.

loans.use: To buy more instruments for his band

loans.name: Imanalu

texts.en: Mrs. Imanalu J. is 51 years old. She is married with six (6) children. She was trained for 2 years before starting her own business, and she hails from Benin City, Nigeria. She hopes to get the above amount to buy materials for her soap business.

loans.use: To buy more material for soap making

loans.name: Titus Wasike

texts.en: Titus is married with two children who have not yet joined school. Though he has finished his secondary school, he has not undertaken any job training. He started his business in 2000 in order to uplift his living standard. He operates a small kiosk at the center of a main market, and he also frequents other markets to increase his customer base. With a loan from PEMCI, he will increase his food stock and be able to buy in bulk (wholesale) and earn more profit on his retail sales. Through his business he has been able to support his family's needs and bring fresh foodstuffs nearer to the community center from local farms.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: "I started this business years ago and it has helped me take care of my family. I know how to safeguard my capital to ensure continuity in business." These are the words of Mrs. Dorcas O., married with four (4) children. She is requesting $250 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is a woman of 47 years old, married with four (4) children, who lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She started her business in the year 1990. She specializes in the sales of foodstuffs. The above amount will be of good help to her in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Christy

texts.en: Christy O. is a woman of 45 years old, married with six (6) children, who lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She started her business in the year 1981. She specializes in the sales of dry gin. The above amount will be of good help to her in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more dry gin

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience O. is 41 years old, and is married with four (4) children. She has been a LAPO client for over 8 years. She sells kerosene to her public, and she lives in Benin City. She wishes the above amount for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sales

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Mrs. Victoria A. lives in Benin City, Edo State,  Nigeria. She is 48 years old and is married with five (5) children. She started her business in the year 2002. She needs the above amount for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Kate Nse

texts.en: Mrs. Kate Nse U. is 32 years old. She lives in the semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She rents video cassettes to people in her neighborhood. She is married with three children. She is a dedicated client of LAPO. She needs the above amount for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more video cassettes

loans.name: Osasere

texts.en: Mrs. Osasere O. is 33 years old. She is married with four (4) children. She has been LAPO client for over 6 years. She lives in Benin City. She wants the above amount for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: Paullina

texts.en: Mrs. Paullina O. is 41 years old. She is married with seven (7) children. She has been a LAPO client for over 4 years. She lives in Benin City. She wants the above amount for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Mrs. Janet A. is 47 years old, with three (3) children. She has been learning the sale of foodstuffs for the past 2 years. She wants $400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Barasa

texts.en: Barasa is married with five children, all in primary school. He started his business in 2002 in order to sustain his family. He has not undertaken any formal training, but he is an active member of his local community’s self help group dealing with poverty eradication and fighting against HIV/AIDS.  With a loan from PEMCI, he will be able to increase his cereals stock and to open a cereal store. Through his business, he has been able to fight hunger in the community and provide a good example to the others in the area.

loans.use: To increase his cereals stock

loans.name: Precious

texts.en: Mrs. Precious N. is 29 years old, with five (5) children. She beautifies people’s hair and sells foodstuffs to her community. She wishes to borrow $400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs & hairdressing equipment

loans.name: Josephine N.

texts.en:
Josephine is married with six children; three are in primary school and three have finished schooling. She has not undertaken any advanced schooling, though she finished her secondary school successfully.

Josephine started her business in 1976 operating with a cereal board. She has a great deal of experience since she has been in the business for a long time. Through the business she has been able to support her children by paying their school fees, meeting their basic needs and providing food security to the community.

With a loan from PEMCI, she intents to increase her stock to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: To boost her business

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Mrs. Queen O. is 39 years old, with seven (7) children. She sells fire wood to her community. She wishes to borrow $400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more firewoods for sales

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent is married with two children in primary school. She is a trained community nurse.

Apart from her nursing career, she operates a self selection shop at the nearby trading centre. She started her business in 2005 in order to supplement her earnings. Through her business, she has been able to support her family's welfare and also the community as a whole since they don’t need to go far to do their shopping.

With a loan from PEMCI, Millicent intents to increase the stock of her shop.

loans.use: To boost her stock

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Mrs. Doris I. is 26 years old married with two (2) children. She beautifies people hair in her community. She hails from Benin, Edo State, Nigeria. Wishes to borrow $150 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more hair dressing equipment

loans.name: Rukia N.

texts.en:
Rukia is a mother of one. She is a trained tailor. She is self-employed, and her business involves dressmaking and selling the clothes to willing customers. She also sometimes sells maize through the local cereal board. She has been in the business for two years. Her tailoring shop is in the trading centre, hence she is able to gain access to customers.

With a loan from PEMCI, Rukia wishes to increase her stock in the cereal business. Through her business, she hopes to start training young girls on design and tailoring.

loans.use: To boost her stock

loans.name: Itohan

texts.en: Mrs. Itohan O. is 42 years old and married with four (4) children. She sells fresh fruit to her community. She wishes to borrow $400 to buy more stock.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fruit for sales

loans.name: Chiyenure

texts.en: A woman of 48 years old and is married with five (5) children.  She beautifies people’s hair in her community. She hails from Benin, Edo State, Nigeria. She wishes to borrow $250 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more waving equipment

loans.name: Maitida

texts.en: Maitida is 32 years old and is married with two (2) children. She sells rubber plastics to people in her community. She hails from Benin, Edo State, Nigeria. She wishes to borrow $400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more plastics for sales

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Mr. Anthony E. is 37 years old from a semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. He delivers the services of panel beating to his community. He is married with three (3) children. He wants to borrow $400 to buy more instruments for his workshop and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more instruments for his workshop

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a 48 year old woman who is married with eight (8) children. She sells used clothing to people in her community. She hails from Benin, Edo State, Nigeria. She wishes to borrow $400 for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing for sales

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is is 39 years old. She is married and the mother of three, ages 17, 18 and 20. Her husband is a mechanic but his income wasn't enough to meet the family's needs, particularly the children's school, which got more and more expensive, so Margarita decided to sell new and somewhat new clothing three years ago. She had the help of a friend who helped her find initial stock. Her business has gone very well and now she has the help of her children and is able to pay for their education. In order to grow her business she is asking for a loan of $100 to buy a greater variety of goods and meet demand. Margarita and her family need your help to continue with their business. The well-being of this home is in your hands, so please decide to support them.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

La señora Margarita tiene 39 años de edad, es casada y madre de tres hijos de 17, 18 y 20 años, su esposo es mecánico y con el ingreso que él recibe no se podían cubrir todas las necesidades de su familia, principalmente de la escuela de sus hijos que cada vez resultaba más costoso, por esta razón Margarita decidió iniciar con la venta de ropa nueva y seminueva hace tres años, con la ayuda de una de sus amigas que le ayudó a surtirse de mercancía. A Margarita le ha ido muy bien en su negocio y ahora cuenta con la colaboración de sus hijos.

Con la unión de la familia Margarita ha podido sacar adelante el negocio y los estudios de sus hijos. Ahora quiere que su negocio continúe creciendo y para esto requiere de un préstamo de sólo $100 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía para tener mayor variedad y poder ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Margarita y su familia necesitan de tu ayuda para poder continuar con su negocio, en tus manos esta el bienestar de este hogar, decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario is a carpenter like generations of his family before him. He is married and has four children. He used to work in his father's shop, but decided to set up a workshop of his own. He is very experienced and is known for his high-quality work which is much in demand. Right now he has orders that he cannot fill because he doesn't have the materials so he is asking for a loan of $250 which he proposes to repay in 3-6 months. With your help Mario can continue working to grow his business and tend to his family. They much appreciate your generosity and support.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Mario se dedica a la carpintería, este oficio ha permanecido generación tras generación en su familia, él es casado y tiene cuatro hijos, trabajaba en el taller de su padre, pero decidió independizarse e iniciar su propio negocio, la experiencia que tiene en este oficio ha permitido que los muebles que fabrica sean de muy buena calidad y muy aceptados por sus clientes, así es como se ha dado a conocer y ha ganando mucha clientela.

En este momento Mario tiene pedidos que no ha podido realizar por falta de material, por lo que solicita un préstamo por $250 dólares, que ofrece devolver en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses. Con tu ayuda Mario podrá seguir trabajando, tú puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la vida de su familia, ellos agradecen tu generosidad y apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Mirna Erika

texts.en:
Mirna is an enterprising woman, the mother of two small children, 3 and 6 years old. She could never count on her partner and has had to raise the children on her own. When she was about to give birth to her last child she was fired from her job so she decided to start a business selling cosmetics to cover her household expenses. At first she helped a friend, then little by little she got her own customers and now she is a distributor and hopes to continue growing her business. Her greatest inspiration to get by day to day is her love for her children. She is asking for a loan of $550 to buy merchandise so she will have a greater variety and be able to meet demand. She proposes to repay the loan in 4 to 8 months. With your help Mirna will be able to continue her business. The well-being of her family is in your hands. Your help is very useful to her and her children and they are all grateful for your generosity.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Mirna es una mujer emprendedora y muy activa, ella tiene dos pequeños hijos de 3 y 6 años, nunca contó con el apoyo de su pareja, por lo que tiene que sacar adelante a sus hijos ella sola, cuando iba a nacer su último hijo Mirna fue despedida de su empleo y para poder obtener un ingreso que le permitiera cubrir los gastos de su hogar decidió iniciar con la venta de cosméticos, primero le ayudaba a una de sus amigas, poco a poco fue ganando clientes e incrementado sus ventas, ahora ya es distribuidora de estos productos y quiere continuar creciendo con su negocio.

El amor hacia sus hijos es el motivo más fuerte que tiene Mirna para superarse día a día, ahora ella necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $550 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía, para tener una mayor variedad y cubrir la demanda de sus clientes, ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. Con tu ayuda Mirna puede continuar con su negocio, en tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, tú apoyo es de gran utilidad para ella y sus hijos, ellos agradecen tu generosidad.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by buying more stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by buying more stock.

loans.name: Hafiz Allah

texts.en: Hafiz Allah lives in District 10 of Kabul Afghanistan. He is 43 years old and lives with six members of his family. He sells carpet-making equipment and took out a previous loan to purchase the machines, the string and materials, and the different patterns used to make carpets. Now Hafiz Allah would like another loan to purchase more equipment which he believes will build his business even more. By purchasing additional materials, he feels it will help expand his customer base and build closer relationships with his already existing clients.

loans.use: To purchase additional carpet-making equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a refrigerator and more stock

loans.name: Mohammad Abriam

texts.en:
M. Abriam is 33 years old. He lives in a household of 8 in District 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a retail food shop and he took his first loan cycle and bought some inventory items like oil, matches, rice, baskets of chocolates and some other things. He does a good business so he is very happy.

He wants to take a loan to buy more of these things to be good shopkeeper. He wants to expand his business and improve his life. Now that he is better than other shopkeepers in the area, he can help his family better.

loans.use: To buy extra inventory items

loans.name: Hadalla

texts.en:
Hadalla lives in District 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is single and lives at home with her family. With her family facing economical problems, she wants to take out a loan for her brother so he can open a metal working shop. Her brother has nine years of experience in metal working and now wants to also work at shining and polishing metal, which requires many tools that he does not have. He would use this loan to buy the additional tools and materials needed for this business. Hadalla and her brother are very happy to support their family.

Note: The picture featured in this business profile is the brother of the entrepreneur, but the loan is to Hadalla. In Afghanistan some people find it culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman on the Internet.

loans.use: To open a metal working shop.

loans.name: Marzia

texts.en: Marzia is 21 years old and lives in a household of four in District 5 of Kabul Afghanistan. She is single and her father was killed during the war in Afghanistan. Since she doesn’t have brothers and also is the youngest in her family, she is the main financial support for her family.  Marzia provides income through knitting at home. She would like a loan to buy more knitting materials which will help her build a good business. This will hopefully provide more income for her family and make a good life for them.

loans.use: To buy additional materials for her knitting business.

loans.name: Hasina

texts.en: Hasina S. J. lives in District 7 of Kabul Afghanistan. She is 24 years old and lives with four other family members. She is married with two children and is good at knitting. Her husband’s income is not enough to cover all the family’s needs so Hasina would like to develop a knitting business to support her husband’s salary. This loan would help her buy the knitting equipment needed to create and expand her business. Hasina’s entire family is very happy and supportive of her and the loan from AFSG.

loans.use: To buy more knitting materials.

loans.name: Soma Sahar

texts.en: Soma Sahar is 38 years old and lives in a household of three in District 4 of Kabul Afghanistan. She started knitting when she was a child, and now has so much experience, she made knitting her professional business. She is very happy with the opportunity to obtain a loan to buy materials such as pine tree trunks, roots, petals and ferns to add to her already existing shop in the bazaar. These items will help bring in more customers and then she will be able to demonstrate how experienced she is in knitting.  Soma wants to increase her business as soon as possible so she can help her family economically.

loans.use: To buy extra materials for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by buying increasing inventory levels.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim S. is 37 years old and is a mototaxi driver.  He lives with his wife 
(pictured here) in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  He can typically earn about $5/day.  His wife works at the local garment factory and can earn around $2/day.  With the loan, S. hopes to use it to repair his house and to purchase a simple motorbike for his family business.  In the future, he expects to buy a grocery store at the market and if possible, build up their home in order to protect it from the rainy season.

loans.use: Purchase motorbike and repair home

loans.name: Mohammad Raza

texts.en: Mohammed Raza lives in District 6 of Kabul Afghanistan. He is married, has three children, and lives in the same house with all his brothers. Although formally uneducated, Mohammed owns a retail food shop and would like a loan to improve and expand its merchandise. He would use this loan to purchase things like rice, milk, baskets, oil, bananas, Pepsi, and maybe even use it to buy and sell telephone calling cards, which Mohammed says is a good business. He wants to work hard and make a good life for himself and believes this loan will help him do that.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for his shop.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim S. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and 4 children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  He makes his living as a mototaxi driver and can typically make around $4/day of income.  His wife, meanwhile, works at the local garment factory and can earn about $2.5/day.  Moreover, one of his children is also a garment worker, which contributes to their household every month and at the same time, three children are students at the school near their home.  With the loan, S. hopes to purchase one motorbike for his children and also wants to change his old motorbike in order to run his daily business.  In the future, S. expects to run a simple grocery business at his house and hopes to build a concrete house for his family.  If he has the opportunity, he would send his children to the local university.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike for children and to fix his motorbike for business

loans.name: Sayaad Mir Mohammad

texts.en: Sayaad M. Mohammad lives in District 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a cosmetics shop keeper. He is a very talented boy because he opened a shop of cosmetics and made it very beautiful. He bought everything and spent a lot on his shop. Now he wants to take a loan to buy different and modern clothes for his shop to introduce to people. He wants to make a good business of cosmetics and make his future because he is single and young.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer, frying pan and a frying spoon

loans.name: Phai Hong

texts.en: PH. Hong H. is 26 years old and lives with his wife and one small child in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  He is a mototaxi driver and generates profits of around $2.5/day.  His wife, Kun Thear, is self-employed as a garment worker and typically earns about $2.5/day.  Besides this, she also runs a small grocery business and contributes her income to the household.  Additionally, the loan allows this family to purchase some grocery items and to repair their house in order to protect it from the rainy season.  In the future, Hong H. hopes to open a simple mechanic store and if possible, he would build a simple concrete house to make hisstandard of living better.  And he would send his child to the local school nearby this village.

loans.use: Purchase grocery items and repair home for rainy season

payments.comment:
Dear Kiva Lender,

Great news! Phai Hong Hai has repaid the Kiva loan early! Kiva and CREDIT MFI make every effort to be as transparent as possible so you can trust the information we give you. In this case, we didn’t let you know that the loan had been repaid at the time. Occasionally, when a loan is repaid early, the payment schedule posted on Kiva doesn’t always match the records of our micro finance partner in Cambodia, CREDIT MFI. As in life, the system doesn’t always run perfectly, but when there is a discrepancy we will alert you as soon as possible so you have all the information about your investment.

On the upside, the issue occurred because the client’s business is so successful! Your loan made that possible. Soon you will see a repayment posted on the client’s profile that is larger than the usual amount. This will end the loan and return the funds to your account. We hope you will choose to loan the repaid funds to another entrepreneur who would a like a chance to grow their business as well. 

If you have any questions, please post them as a comment on this borrowers site and I will be happy to respond. I also encourage you to write comments on the pages of your loan recipients so we can pass along your good wishes to the borrowers.

We sincerely apologize for the oversight and are putting policies in place to make sure that it doesn’t happen again. Thank you for giving poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia a chance at success! 

Best regards,

Sopheap Khiev, Kiva partnership coordinator, Cambodia
Mr. Chan Mach, General Manager, CREDIT MFI, Cambodia

loans.name: Johnstone

texts.en:
Johnstone Kyalo M. is a 31-year-old married man with one child. He lives in Mlolongo, an informal settlement along the Mombasa-Nairobi highway. Kyalo also takes care of his aging mother and two children from his paternal uncle, who is unemployed and cannot take care of them. Kyalo has to make sure that his uncle’s children go to school, are clothed, and eat healthy food daily.

Kyalo started his business in 2005 after 4 years of working at the Kulshan tailoring shop in Nairobi. During this period (2000-2005), Kyalo was employed by an Indian national, and his job was to sew round buttonholes. After some time, Kyalo realized that sewing round buttonholes was a dead-end job, and he approached a colleague, asking to be trained as a tailor. His colleague accepted, provided Kyalo paid for the training. Kyalo trained for 3 years and became an expert tailor.

In April 2005, Kyalo decided that it was no longer worthwhile to stay in his job, and he left to start his own business. Armed with Ksh. 15,000 (USD 214) that he had saved over time, Kyalo bought a second-hand sewing machine and some cloth, and he started tailoring skirts and dresses for small girls. He took these dresses to the open-air market, where they sold like hot cakes. The business is doing well.

Now Kyalo wants to expand his business, because he gets more clients every day. He now employs 3 helpers, creating employment opportunities in the community.

Johnston Kyalo is kindly asking for a loan of USD 525. With the loan, he intends to purchase more cloth and other materials, including zippers, hooks, thread, canvas, shoulder pads, buttons, and lining materials. He hopes to set a shining example of self-employment. He intends to pay back the loan, within 8 to 14 months.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, zippers, hooks, threads, and buttons

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn S. is a father of two children, is 35 years old, and lives with his wife and family in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  He is a tuk-tuk driver and can typically generate around $10/day of income.  His wife, meanwhile, works at the local garment factory and can earn about $3/day.  Furthermore, one of his children is a student and another is too young to begin school.  S. hopes to use the loan to purchase one moto Tuk-tuk in order to run his business.  In the future, he would be really grateful if he can extend his current business and make more income to supply his family with.

loans.use: To purchase Tuk-tuk (motorbike with passenger cart) for his business

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann Wamaitha K. is a 53-year-old married woman who cares for her 3 children and 2 of her sister's children. Her sister can't take care of her two children, and Ann has taken them on as her own, housing and educating them. Ann lives in Mlolongo, an informal settlement along Nairobi-Mombasa highway.

Ann’s story is one of the phoenix rising from ashes. Ann started her business in 1997 with savings of Ksh 1500 (USD 21). With this samll amount of seed money, Ann started a tailoring business in a wooden structure called a “kibanda” in Swahili. As fate would have it, Ann was involved in an accident in 1998, which left her with an injured spinal cord and a broken left arm. Ann needed metal plates in her arm and was confined to bed rest for 3 years.

In 2000 she recovered a bit and borrowed Ksh 5,000 (USD 71) from her husband, who was moved by Ann's determination. With this money she bought plastic items (cups, plates, trays, jugs, basins) and sufurias (cooking pots) and started selling food in a small stall. The business did so well that, in July 2006, she managed to rent a shop for Ksh 2,500 (USD 36) in Mlolongo. So far she has taken out three small loans of Ksh. 10,000 (USD 145) from a small NGO society (COSWE), which lends a maximum of USD 145 to people starting out in business. She has so far managed to repay the loans. Through God’s grace and with the small loans she has received, Ann has managed to increase her inventory.

Because the community is getting larger every day, she would like to increase her stock even more and offer new goods, including knitting yarn, baby clothes, blankets, and bedsheets.

Ann is kindly asking for a loan of USD 775 with which to stock her shop and serve the community better. The repayment period is 8-14 months.

loans.use: To purchase stock for a general shop including knitting yarn, baby clothes, blankets, and  bedsheets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a computer, scanner, and printer

loans.name: Hadi

texts.en:
Hadi lives in District 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is uneducated and her father is dead. Her family has an economical problem at home. She has a brother who has a retail food shop and he needs money. His sister is taking a loan from AFSG for her brother to buy more materials for the shop, like rice baskets and milk, to make a good life for his family. He is the only one to help his family and he wants to find close relationships with people to find more clients to make a better life for his family.

Note: The picture in this business profile is the brother entrepreneur. In Afghanistan it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet, but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: To buy extra things

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mon V., a 42-year-old father of 2 children , lives with his wife (pictured here) in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He makes his living as a carpenter and usually makes around $5 per day of income. His wife is self-employed as a garment worker and can typically earn about $2.3 aday. V.'s older daughter is a small grocer and can contribute a small amount of profit to the household. Another is a student at the local school nearby his house and often gets involved with his sister's business when he is free from his class. With the loan, V. hopes to use it to buy some grocery items for his daughter to run her business and the rest is to repair his moto-bike. In the future, he expects to open a big grocery shop and wants to build up his house. One more hope is to send his children to the local university.

loans.use: To purchase stock for grocery store and repair motorbike.

loans.name: Mazgan

texts.en: Mazgan is 30 years old and lives with members of her family in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a tailor and she has 8 years' experience in her job. She wants to take out a loan to buy new machines to increase her business. This will help her find good relationships with people to make a good monthly income to help and support her family. She is very happy now and she would like to thank AFSG.

loans.use: To buy extra machines

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A., 25, belongs to the Acholi tribe. She was born in Atiak county, Kal parish, in the Amuru district. Beatrice lost her father and an uncle and was forced to flee to Gulu town by the Lord's Resistance Army, which made her face terrible hardships. Beatrice is the firstborn, and she lost her father at a tender age.

Since 1998 Beatrice has been involved in and earned a small living doing voluntary work with the Ugandan Red Cross Society and later with the Charity for Peace center. In 2006, she registered as a Life in Africa member and is currently committed to her work with that community.

Beatrice is single and a tailor by profession. She participates in Life in Africa crafts programmes making bracelets, paper beads, bags fashioned from drinking straws, and so on.

Her plan is to spend 250,000= (shillings) on second-hand clothes. Her younger sister Concy will sell the clothes, and Beatrice will continue with her crafts. This will increase her income by 340,000= per month.

She plans to repay in 6 months.

Below is her budget plan:

A bale of second-hand clothes.......................=180,000=

Loading fee...............................................3,000=

Off loading.................................................3,000=

Market dues..........................................9,000=@month

Salary..................................250,000=

loans.use: Purchasing second hand clothes

loans.name: Finny

texts.en:
Finny belongs to the Acholi tribe and works with the Charity for Peace Foundation, based in the Gulu District. She is a camp trainer focusing on savings and loans and psychosocial development. She trained as an accountant. She has three children, Oroma Brenda, Bedogwa Brian, and Oyella Sheila. Their father died in the war in northern Uganda.

All Finny's children go to primary school. She provides for her children by running a small shop and working part time with community organizations like CfP and Life in Africa. She loves her job as a trainer so much that it makes her forget her problems. When in the camp training the women, she loves sharing with them and helping them to cope with the prevailing situation, and she makes sure that happiness and love come first in her work. Life in Africa (LiA) is teaching Finny how to become an Internet4change agent who connects people to online loans.

Finny currently operates a small shop selling biscuits, detergents, packaged foodstuffs, and other items. She plans to use her loan to stock sodas, which she currently doesn't carry in her shop, and to rent a freezer to keep them cold. She also plans to hire someone at a salary of 50,000= a month to help her, because she's become so busy with her work in camps and LiA that it's hard to run the business alone. She currently earns 200,000 shillings per month from her business and expects that after this investment she will earn 300,000 shillings per month.

If offered the loan, she plans to repay it in 3 months.

Below is Finny's budget plan

10 crates................................97,000=
,br> 10 Empty crate deposit.....................80,000= Transport....................................5,000=
br> Freezer rental..............................15,000= Salary.......................................50,000= Others.........................................3,000= Total......................................250,000=

loans.use: Buying Sodas

loans.name: Manizha

texts.en:
Manizha is 45 years old and lives in a household in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is widowed because her husband died during the war. She needs money because her son has a car part business. She wants to take a loan for her son to increase the business and buy more car kits to help his family and help his brothers to join him in school and support all parts of his family.

Note: the picture featured in this business profile is the son entrepreneur. In Afghanistan it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: To buy car parts

loans.name: Morrish

texts.en:
Morrish M. is 20 years old and currently working with the Life in Africa We center in Gulu, Uganda. He is also a volunteer with Charity for Peace, a non-profit organization in Northern Uganda working with the Night Commuter children. He stays in the Kolo quarter, living alone. He is not yet married and has no children, but he would like to start a family. However, he is wise enough to know that before starting a family he needs to establish himself in a business that will sustain them.

He lost his father in 1994 and was reared by his mother, Jostina Kawa, in Fort Portal. But he dreamed of returning home, and so in 2003, when he was in grade senior four (4), he decided to return to the Kolo quarter, where his father died.

Because of his own experience as an orphan, he was drawn to the children affected by the war in the North. Helping them has helped him to cope with his own situation, and he has learned the joy of sharing and exchanging ideas with many people around the world. His love of God and his determination to help others makes him a valuable asset to his community.

Morrish developed an interest in business while working with Life in Africa's bead project. After careful thought, he has decided to start a business selling goats. He will employ someone to help him when he is working at the bead project, and he plans to pay this person with a share of the profits. This should be a profitable business because goat meat is very popular with the people of this region, and goats are used in traditional ceremonies as well. His business plan shows that he can make a 40% profit each week on his investment. This money combined with what he earns in the bead project will enable him to have a better life, repay the loan, and perhaps start his own family.

Acording to his business plan he will need a loan in the amount of 250,000=/ (Ugandan shillings) to start his business. He is very confident that he will be able to repay this loan in 3 months.

M. has savings of 300,000= (three hundred thousand shillings only) which will go toward renting a place from which to sell his goats and paying the salary of the person who will help him run the business while he is at work.

Business plan.

Transport............................................15,000=

License...............................................5,000=

Buying 15 goats.....................................220,000=

05ropes..............................................5,000=

contigency............................................5,000=

Grand total.........................................250,000=

loans.use: Buying Goats

loans.name: Mir Habas

texts.en: Mir Habas lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a shopkeeper. He has a dress shop. He has experience working as a shopkeeper and he wants to improve his business to make his shop bigger. Now he wants to take a loan and buy more clothes for the shop to find more clients and increase his business. It is one of his best wishes and also a good chance for him to work hard and further this business. He is sure that he can help his family now.

loans.use: To buy new clothes

loans.name: Mir Mohammad Zia

texts.en: Mir M. Zia lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan with all the members of his family. He is married and has three children and he is a clothing seller in the main city of Kabul. He is new in his work. He wants to improve his business and take a loan to buy extra materials, like t-shirts and new designs of clothes for the youngest people, so that he makes a good business to help his family and support them and send his children to good schools. He is the only one that works for his family and he wants to be a good businessman in the future.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.en:
Sharifa lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan with the six members of her family. She is married and she supports her husband. She took two loans and her husband spent them on his car and bought tires. Now she wants to take another loan because her husband wants to improve the engine of the car and also change the color of the car. He wants to find more clients and have a better relationship with the construction companies to make a good monthly income for his family to help them.

Note: the picture featured in this business profile is the husband entrepreneur. In Afghanistan it is culturally unacceptable to post a picture of a woman to the internet but the loan is to the female entrepreneur.

loans.use: To buy extra materials

loans.name: Alima

texts.en: Alima lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan with the members of her family. She is a tailor and also  she cleans fruits. She took a loan and bought sewing machines and did good business with that and supported her family. She has the responsibility of her house and she wants to expand her business. In this case she wants to take another loan and buy modern machines to help her family and do something for the future of her children.

loans.use: To buy more machines

loans.name: Margaret Adionyi

texts.en:
Margaret is married with five children all in primary school. She has not undergone any formal training. She started her business in 2005 in order to sustain her family. She repaid her first loan successfully with PEMCI, which helped her strengthen her capital base. Through her business she has been able to gain skills in business management and to bring shopping services closer to the local community.

With the proposed second loan, she intends to increase her stock further and improve her income. As a woman who is trying to promote the well-being of her family, she is worth the support.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Evans  M.

texts.en:
Evans is married with four children all in primary school. He has not undertaken any training but hopes to join college soon.

He sells bicycle spare parts to service the large number of bicycles in this local environment. He started his business in 2000 in order to support his family.

With a loan from PEMCI, Evans intends to improve on his stock and be able to supply goods to other shopkeepers in the area. Through his business, he has been able to supply the local bodabodas (cyclists) with cheap spare parts.

loans.use: To boost his stock

loans.name: Alfred Simiyu

texts.en:
Alfred started his business in 2002. He is a trained engineer and a retired policeman. He operates a small workshop where he sells car and truck batteries, spare parts, and tyres. He also operates a small filling station. He has a total of 3 employees.

With the loan of $750 from PEMCI, Alfred intends to increase his stock of spare parts. Through his business, he has been able to provide employment and a source of livelihood for himself and his family. He is a shrewd businessman who is contributing to the economic activity within his local area and well worth the funding by Kiva partners.

loans.use: To boost his stock

loans.name: Stephen Wafula

texts.en:
Stephen is married with four children in primary and secondary schools. He is a primary school dropout and has not undertaken any formal training.

Stephen started his cereals and grocery selling business in 1989 in order to support his family. He is an active member of Angurai Anglican community, in which he is preacher at the Sunday school. Through his business, he has been able to buy a dairy cow that supplies milk for his family and to pay school fees for their children. He is also able to support the extended family and his local church orphanage.

With the loan of $150 from PEMCI, he intends to increase his stock and hence improve his profitability. As an active member of his community, Stephen is a role model who can have a very positive influence on the people around him. He is therefore worth support from Kiva partners.

loans.use: To boost his stock

loans.name: 'tanti Cecile'

texts.en:
C. is a widowed woman leaving with 3 children in Anono a township in the eastern suburb of Abidjan. C. is doing the grilled meet & fish sale business to pay the whole life expenses of her family (children school expenses, family foods, clothes, etc.).  C. wants to develop her activities in order to be able to pay the grammar school in September 2007 for her first daughter (10 years) who will finish primary school in June 2007. She will use the loan to buy a deep freezer (refrigerator) in order to be able to purchase in bulk beef meet and fish and stock for further retail sell after she has grilled them. The grilled meet and fish activities are the only revenues resource for C. and her family.
C. heard about AE&I in Dec. 2005 from other women operating in her area. She has got since then, different microcrédits from AE&I, that she totally reimbursed timely.
C. is a dynamic woman.

loans.use: The loan will be used to buy a deep freezer (refrigerator) in which she can stock fresh meet and fish that she will grill before selling

loans.name: Finike  Etyang

texts.en:
Finike is married with six children: one in college, two in secondary school and the rest in primary school. She has undergone secretarial training used to work at the divisional headquarters.

Finike started her business as a fishmonger and cereals trader in 1998 in order to improve her sources of income and to support her husband in paying school fees for their children. Through her skills she has also been able to bring some secretarial services closer to her local community.

With the loan of $125 from PEMCI, she plans to increase her stock. Well worth of support from Kiva partners.

loans.use: To boost her stock

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en:
Consolata is married with three children in primary schools. She has a diploma in metal works, a very rare and unique qualification for a woman in these parts.

Consolata started her metal work business in 2003 dealing mainly in window frames, gates and other metal equipment. Through her business she has been able to provide employment to three local people.

With the loan of $150 from PEMCI she plans to increase her stock of metal to meet the growing demand for window frames and doors in her local area. Her business has good potential for growth in view of the booming construction industry. She has also been very creative in the fabrication of steel products, which has made her popular in the local area. She is a role model for other women in her community and deserves support to grow.

loans.use: To boost her stock

loans.name: Daniel Wafula

texts.en:
Daniel is married with three children. He has not undergone any formal training, although he has attended seminars for youth groups, where he was taught measurers of poverty eradication. He runs a food kiosk in his local area but also sells firewood to supplement his income. He also supplies some local schools with firewood.

With the loan of $150 from PEMCI he intends to expand his firewood business and also increase his stock. Recommended for support by PEMCI partners.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Eliud Wangila

texts.en:
Eliud is a young man who is not yet married. He started his hawking business in 2005 after secondary school. He is also a farmer specializing in tobacco, where he works hand-in-hand with his father. Through his business, he has been able to support his parents to pay school fees for his sibling.

With the loan of $150 from PEMCI, he intends to increase his stock of utensils and kitchenware. This way he will be able to move to different markets, hence expanding his sales and profits. As a youth, Eliud is a good role model for those aspiring to start their own businesses. In view of the unemployment situation, many youth are encouraged to seek self-employment as a way of earning their livelihood. Well worth the support of Kiva partners.

loans.use: To increase capital

loans.name: Karina Del Rosario

texts.en:
Karina has been making furniture for 13 years. Her two brothers and a nephew work beside her a workshop established by her father more than forty years ago. She is the single mother of two, a seven-year-old and a ten-month-old. She cannot count on the support of her partner and must provide for the children on her own. Sadly, her father passed away, so Karina must help provide for her mother as well. She has good experience and makes high-quality furniture which is much in demand. She needs a $750 loan to purchase lumber, nails, paint and varnish. Please help her grow this business and improve her family's quality of life. They would sincerely appreciate your help.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer Alexis Hult

Karina trabaja en la carpintería desde hace 13 años, este negocio lo inició su padre hace más de 40 años, aquí también trabajan dos de sus hermanos y un sobrinos. Karina es madre soltera de dos hijos, de 7 años y de 10 meses de edad, no tiene el apoyo de su pareja y tiene que solventar los gastos de sus hijos ella sola, lamentablemente su padre falleció y también tiene que ayudar económicamente a su madre.

Con base en la experiencia, los muebles que fabrican son de muy buena calidad y los pedidos por sus productos se han incrementado, en estos momentos necesitan de un crédito por $775 dólares que destinará a la compra del material que requiere para la elaboración de su trabajo, como madera, pintura, clavos y lacas. Contribuye al crecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a widow and the mother of five. She has worked in a garment factory for many years. Even when her husband was alive she had to work to provide for her family, and so it was that 16 years ago she set up her own tailor's shop. She worked hard to grow her business and support her children. Her business is growing and in addition to many requests she now makes the athletic uniforms for an elementary school. It hasn't been easy to survive the loss of her husband and support her family single-handledly, but Virginia's love for her children drives her on. She is asking for a loan of $200 that she will use to buy cloth, thread and other materials to continue her business. She proposes to repay the loan in 3 to 6 months. You can play an essential role in this business and in the life of this family. They very much appreciate your support and generosity.

Translated by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Virginia es viuda y tiene cinco hijos, ella trabajó en una maquiladora de ropa hace muchos años, ya casada tuvo la necesidad de obtener un ingreso extra para ayudar con los gastos del hogar y así fue como, aprovechando la experiencia que tenía, inicio hace 16 años su propio taller de costura, lamentablemente falleció su esposo y para sacar adelante a sus hijos trabajó arduamente en su taller, ahora su negocio ha crecido y cuanta con muchos pedidos de sus clientes, además que elabora los uniformes deportivos de una escuela primaria.

No ha sido fácil para Virginia superar la perdida de su esposo y tener que sostener a su familia sin ayuda, pero el amor a sus hijos ha sido su gran motivo para lograrlo, ahora ella requiere un préstamo por $ 200 dólares que empleará en la compra de telas, hilos y los materiales que necesita para continuar trabajando y ofrecerle a sus clientes un servicio de calidad, ella ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses. Tú puedes ser parte fundamental en este negocio y en la vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen tu generosidad y apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.en:
Maria Guadalupe lives in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon. She is married and has four children aged 14, 16 and 18. To proviD. for her family she has worked for five years alongsiD. one of her sister-in-law making tamales. Later she prepared food for laborers doing construction near her home. She works hard to grow her business and little by little wins new customers. Right now Maria needs a $375 loan to buy ingredients for her tamales, which are much in demand. She proposes to repay the loan in 5 to 10 months. If you can help Maria with this, she and her family will sincerely appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Maria Guadalupe vive en Monterrey, Nuevo León, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos, D. 18, 16 y 14 años D. edad, L. necesidad D. ayudar con los gastos del hogar L. incentivaron a trabajar con una D. sus cuñadas ayudándole en L. elaboración D. tamales hace cinco años, después tuvo L. oportunidad D. hacer comidas para personas que trabajan en una construcción cerca D. su casa, y poco a poco se fue ganando clientes, ahora surte numerosos pedidos D. tamales, su negocio ha estado creciendo poco a poco y María se esfuerza día cada día por sacarlo adelante.

En estos momentos Maria necesita D. un préstamo por L. cantidad D. $ 375 dólares que utilizará para L. compra D. los ingredientes que requiere para elaborar pedidos D. tamales que tiene D. sus clientes, elL. ofrece devolver este crédito en un lapso D. 5 a 10 meses. Tú puedes ayudar a Maria a que continúe creciendo, elL. y su familia agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Zulema Margarita

texts.en:
Zulema is married and has two small children ages 2 and 5. Her husband's salary didn't meet the needs of her growing family so two years ago she began selling hamburgers on the weekends. Later, her mother-in-law asked her to help make and sell tamales. She has now set up on her own and is growing her business little by little, driven on by her love for her family. To meet demand for her tamales, Zulema needs a loan for $375 to buy ingredients. To serve her customers well and grow her business, Zulema would very much appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Zulema es casada y tiene dos pequeños hijos de 2 y 5 años de edad. Hace dos años al ver que los gastos familiares se incrementaban y que el salario de su esposo no alcanzaba a cubrirlos, decidió iniciar con la venta de hamburguesas los fines de semana, después tuvo la invitación de su suegra a ayudarle en la elaboración y venta de tamales, actualmente decidió independizarse y cuenta con numerosos pedidos de tamales, poco a poco ha visto crecer su negocio y el amor hacia su familia la han incentivado a esforzarse cada día más.

Para poder cubrir la demanda de los productos que Zulema elabora, ella requiere de un préstamo por $ 375 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los ingredientes que necesita para la elaboración de los tamales. Para poder ofrecer un buen servicio a sus clientes y hacer crecer su negocio, Zulema necesita de tu ayuda, ella y agradece tu generosidad y cariño.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Maria Velia

texts.en:
Maria Velia is married and has four children. Her husband is a laborer but his earnings alone were insufficient to support the family, so Maria decided she needed to help earn money as well. First she tried selling nuts and snacks on the street, but she didn't earn much, so about 10 years ago she started selling tamales. She now has many customers and is able to pay for her children's education so they can get ahead. Maria now needs a $375 loan to buy ingredients because she has orders for her tamales she cannot fill for lack of them. She proposes to repay the loan in 5 to 10 months. With this help she can continue to provide good service and grow her business. Please support her and play an important role in the life of this family.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Velia es casada y tiene cuatro hijos, su esposo es obrero y al no contar con los recursos necesarios para el sustento de su familia, ella decidió apoyar a su esposo con los gastos e inició vendiendo semillas y botanas, pero de esta manera no obtenía los suficiente, así que empezó a vender tamales hace aproximadamente 10 años, ahora sus clientes y pedidos son numerosos, ella ha podido hacer crecer su negocio y ayudar a sus hijos a que puedan estudiar y salir adelante.

En estos momentos, Maria necesita de un crédito de $ 375 dólares que utilizará en la compra de los insumos que requiere para la elaboración de tamales, , porque tiene pedidos que no ha podido surtir por la falta de estos ingredientes, ella ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un plazo de 5 a 10 meses. Con esta ayuda María puede continuar creciendo y ofrecer un buen servicio a sus clientes, tú puedes ser parte importante en la vida de esta familia, apóyalos.

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.en:
Ana, originally from San Luis Potosi, moved to Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, seeking better opportunity. She is married and is the mother of three--3,7 and 9 years of age. Her husband is a laborer but he doesn't earn enough to fully support the family so two years ago Ana took up an invitation from a friend to start her own business selling cosmetics. Little by little, she has found customers among her friends and neighbors and now has plenty of orders. She presently needs a $250 loan to buy merchandise already ordered by her customers. She proposes to repay the loan in 3 to 6 months. She needs your help to continue her business and support her family. The well-being of her family is in your hands, so please do not hesitate and decide to support her.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Ana es originaria de San Luis Potosí, y en busca de mejores oportunidades se mudó a Monterrey, Nuevo León. Ella es casada y tiene tres hijos, de 9, 7 y 3 años de edad. Su esposo es obrero y el salario que recibe es muy poco, no alcanza para cubrir todas las necesidades de su hogar, es por esto que Ana, ante la invitación de una de sus amigas, decidió inicia su propio negocio con la venta de cosméticos hace dos años, poco a poco ha estado ganado clientes, entre sus vecinos y conocidos, ahora cuenta con numerosos pedidos.

Para poder cubrir la demanda de sus clientes, Ana necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 250 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía que ya le han pedido sus clientes, ella devolverá este crédito en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses. Ana necesita de tu ayuda para continuar con su trabajo y para apoyar a su familia, en tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, no lo dudes más y decídete apoyarla.

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia is 55 and has been living in Monterrey for 38 years. She was born in Doctor Arroyo, Nuevo Leon, but she moved seeking opportunity. She has always worked cooking food to help her husband support the family, and ten years ago she began selling tamales by the dozen. She now sells them with her neighbors and every Thursday her daughter distributes them at the factory where whe works. Silvia's husband is a blacksmith and his shop is connected to there home. She is currently asking for a $275 loan to be able to meet demand for her tamales. She proposes to repay the loan in 4 to 8 months. You can be an essential role in the growth of this business and the life of Silvia's family. Please do not hesitate and support them.

Translated by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Doña Silvia tiene 55 años y 38 de estar viviendo en Monterrey, ella nació en Doctor Arroyo, Nuevo León, pero cambio su residencia en busca de mejores oportunidades desde muy joven. Siempre ha trabajado y vendido comidas, con la finalidad de generar ingresos adicionales para el mantenimiento de su hogar y apoyo a su esposo, pero hace 10 años inició el negocio de venta de tamales por docenas y actualmente los vende con sus vecinas y una de sus hijas los distribuye cada jueves en la fábrica donde trabaja. Su esposo es herrero y tiene su negocio en de su propio domicilio.

Actualmente solicita el crédito por la cantidad de $ 275 dólares para poder surtir los pedidos que constantemente le solicitan, ella ofrece devolver este préstamo en un plazo de 4 a 8 meses. Tú puedes ser parte fundamental en el crecimiento de este negocio y en la vida Silvia y su familia, no lo pienses más y decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Maria Eufemia

texts.en:
In 1993, Eufemia began her business to be able to help her husband, but she only sold toast and sweets. Little by little she expanded her business to what it is today: a grocery store with a large inventory. She is married, and her husband is a machinist. They have three children: Aleyda, Rafael, and Carlos who are 19, 17 and 13. They all help with the store. With her experience she knows that now is a good time to further expand her business since sales are greater during the current season. Bringing a new push to her business will definitely be of great benefit.

Now Eufemia needs a $650 loan to buy merchandise to increase her inventory, offer good service, and satisfy the needs and desires of her clients. The growth of this business is in your hands, please don't wait any longer. Support this family.

En 1993 doña Eufemia inició su negocio con la finalidad de ayudar a su esposo, pero solo vendía tostadas y dulces, y poco a poco lo ha hecho crecer hasta convertirlo en lo que es hoy, una tienda de abarrotes con un buen surtido. Ella es una mujer casada y su esposo es empleado maquinista, tienen tres hijos, Aleyda, Rafael y Carlos, de 19, 17 y 13 años de edad respectivamente, los cuales ayudan a atender el negocio. Con su experiencia sabe que ahora es una buena oportunidad de hacer crecer su negocio aún más porque en esta temporada las ventas son mayores, seguramente la beneficiará, trayendo un nuevo empuje para su negocio.

Ahora Eufemia necesita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 650 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía que le permita tener un mejor surtido, poder ofrecer un buen servicio y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes, para conservar su preferencia, en tus manos está el crecimiento de este negocio, no lo pienses más y apoya a esta familia.

loans.use:
To purchase merchandise

Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro is originally from Torreón, Coahuila, but more than ten years ago he decided to relocate so that his family could have a better quality of life. He found a better job in Monterrey and has been working every afternoon as a machinist, and during mornings and weekends he sells clothing to neighbors and friends alongside his wife Isabel. His customers pay him weekly or every two weeks. Since he has a large clientele and accounts to bill, he is assured a prosperous business for a long time.

Now Pedro is asking for a $925 loan to purchase merchandise for the next warm season so that he can provide a variety of products to his clients. He will pay the loan back in 6 to 12 months. The growth of this business and the welfare of this family are in your hands. Please choose to support them.

Don Pedro es originario de Torreón Coahuila, hace mas de 10 años él decidió mover su residencia con la finalidad de mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia, y lo logró porque en Monterrey encontró un mejor empleo, en el que inició desde que llegó a esta ciudad, donde trabaja por las tardes como operario y en las mañanas y fines de semana vende ropa en compañía de su esposa Isabel con los vecinos de la colonia y amistades cercanas, recibiendo de ellos pagos cada semana o quincena, ya tiene una gran cantidad de clientes y cuentas por cobrar que le aseguran tener un negocio prospero por mucho tiempo.

Actualmente Pedro solicita un préstamo de $ 925 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía, para la próxima temporada de calor y poder tener variedad para ofrecer a sus clientes, él se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 6 a 12 meses. E n tus manos esta el crecimiento de este negocio y el bienestar de esta familia, decídete a apoyarlos.

loans.use:
To purchase merchandise

Compra de mercancía

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
Ms Francisca is a 43-year-old native of Monterrey, New Leon, and she has, along with her husband, dedicated herself for 20 years to the daily production and sale of bread. Her bakery business, which also employs her husband and daughter, is the only source of income for her family. It was more than 20 years ago when Francisca recognized the necessity to generate an income to support her children; she decided to start selling bread. She first began production in small quantity. Then, little by little she acquired her gas ovens, which allowed her to increase her production and to convert her business into a supplier of bread to grocery stores. She also produces cakes for children’s parties, fifteenth birthday celebrations, and weddings. With the help of her van she also sells bread on the streets of the community.

Right now she seeks a loan of 1,100 dollars with the aim of buying a higher-capacity mixer, facilitating an increase in production and, hence, growth. She intends to pay back this loan within 3 to 6 months. The family greatly appreciates your support in the growth of this business and the wellbeing of this family.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Francisca es originaria de Monterrey, Nuevo León, tiene 43 años y tiene 20 años de dedicarse junto con su esposo a la elaboración de pan para su venta diaria. Tiene un negocio de panadería que trabaja junto con su esposo y su hija, logrando hacer de este la única fuente de ingresos para la familia. Hace más de 20 años cuando se vio en la necesidad generar ingresos para el sustento de sus hijos, decidió comenzar a vender pan primero en pequeñas cantidades y poco a poco adquirió sus hornos de gas, que le permitieron comenzar a producir más para así convertirse en proveedora de tiendas de abarrotes y elaborar pasteles para fiestas infantiles, XV años y bodas., además, con ayuda de su camioneta también vende pan por las calles de la colonia.

Actualmente necesita un crédito por $ 1,100 dólares con la finalidad de comprar una batidora con más capacidad que le permita tener facilidad de incrementar la producción y así seguir creciendo como lo ha hecho hasta ahora, ella ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un plazo de 3 a 6 meses. Contribuye al crecimiento de este negocio y al bienestar de esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase cooking implements

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.en:
Rosa Maria is a 40-year-old native of Hualahuises, New Leon. At a young age her parents moved to Monterrrey where the family has lived ever since. Her husband has worked in the United States for several years. Rosa Maria has four children; two are married, and one of the two adolescent children, who are economically dependent on Rosa, is currently studying. She began her business to drive the economy of her home; the food she sells also includes tamales and desserts. She sells these locally and through special orders made by her clients.

At this moment, she seeks a loan of 325 dollars to be used in the purchase of materials and business capital to increase her sales. She intends to pay back this loan within 4-8 months. You can help contribute to the improvement of this family’s way of life; Rosa Maria seeks your support and appreciates any help you can lend.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa Maria tiene 40 años de edad y es originaria de Hualahuises, Nuevo León, desde niña sus papás se mudaron a Monterrey, donde ha vivido toda su vida y ahora con sus hijos, su esposo esta trabajando en Estados Unidos desde hace varios años. Rosa Maria tiene 4 hijos, dos casados y dos adolescentes que aun están estudiando y dependen de ella económicamente. Razón por la cual ella comenzó a trabajar para impulsar la economía de su hogar, iniciando su negocio de venta de comidas, también hace tamales y postres, los cuales vende con sus vecinos y también cuando sus clientes le hacen encargos especiales.

En estos momentos requiere un crédito por la cantidad de $ 325 dólares que empleará en la comprar de materiales y capital de trabajo para poder incrementar sus ventas, ella ofrece devolver este préstamo en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. Tú puedes contribuir a mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia, Rosa Maria necesita de tu apoyo y agradece cualquier ayuda que puedas brindarle.

loans.use: To purchase consumables

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en:
Ms Luisa is 50 years old, and she was born in the Estacion14 in the state of San Luis Potosi. She has resided for more than 40 years in Monterrey, to where her parents moved when she was a child. She has dedicated 5 years to making seasonal handicrafts for Valentine’s Day, Mother’s Day, Graduation, etc., and selling arrangements for special events. She started this business with the aim of helping her husband Rogelio, an albino, with a small additional income.

At this moment, she seeks a loan of 325 dollars to purchase the required material for the production of floral arrangements and to be able to have them with anticipation for upcoming Mother’s Day—when sales increase. She intends to pay back the loan within 4-8 months. Luisa and her family greatly appreciate your generosity and support toward the growth of this business.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Luisa tiene 50 años de edad y nació en la localidad de Estación 14 en el estado de San Luis Potosí, tiene más de 40 años viviendo en Monterrey, ya que sus padres se mudaron desde que era niña. Tiene 5 años dedicándose a hacer manualidades en temporadas, como el 14 de febrero, día de las madres, fines de cursos escolares, vendiendo arreglos para eventos especiales. Comenzó a vender con la finalidad de ayudar a su esposo Rogelio, que es albañil, con un pequeño ingreso adicional.

En estos momentos requiere de un crédito por $ 325 dólares para poder comprar el material que requiere para la elaboración de los arreglos florales y poder tenerlos con anticipación, porque se acerca el día de las madres, y es cuando las ventas de sus productos se incrementan, ella ofrece devolver esta cantidad en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. Contribuye al crecimiento de este negocio, Luisa y su familia agradecen sinceramente tu cariño y apoyo.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Nicacia

texts.en:
Nicacia and her husband Cirilo Huanca grow vegetables in Coani, an agricultural region near La Paz, and sell them in the city. They are 63 and 60 years old, respectively. Their children are now grown and independent, so they live on their own. Their three-room home is in Pasankeri, on the west side of the city. It is now surrounded by a a wall of galvanized metal. This loan will pay for a retaining wall that will serve as the foundation for a wall or fence to be built later. This is their fifth loan. Their socio-economic history shows they will be able to repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Nicacia junto a su esposo Cirilo Huanca, se dedican al cultivo de hortalizas en la localidad de Coani, provincia agrícola próxima a la ciudad de La Paz y a la venta de los mismos en un puesto de venta en esta ciudad. Tienen 63 y 60 años respectivamente, sus hijos son independientes, por lo que la señora Nicacia y su esposo viven solos. Su vivienda que se encuentra en la zona de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad, cuenta con tres habitaciones de adobe pero esta amurallado provisionalmente con calaminas metálicas. El crédito solicitado será destinado a construir un muro de contención que será base para el amurallado perimetral que construirán posteriormente. Este es el quinto crédito al que acceden y los antecedentes socio-económicos muestran que podrán cumplir con sus obligaciones sin dificultad.

loans.use: Home renovation.

loans.name: Edelberto

texts.en:
Edelberto, his wife Rosa Paucara and their four dependent children live in Pasankeri on the west side of La Paz. Edelberto is a baker by profession and has been employed for 15 years in a bakery in Cotahuma, near their home. Out of his salary, he has saved enough start-up capital to buy ingredients for his own business like flour, sugar and shortening or lard. This loan will pay for a brick oven in his home so he can work independently. This is his first loan, but his background shows he can improve his income and repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva volunteer Alexis Hult

Edelberto junto a su esposa Rosa Paucara, tienen cuatro hijos aun dependientes, viven en la zona de Pasankeri ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz. El señor Edelberto Q. es de oficio panadero y trabaja como empleado hace quince años, en una panadería de la zona Cotahuma, próxima a su domicilio. Con el sueldo que en la panificadora gana mensualmente, el señor Edelberto Q. pudo ahorrar y comprar productos para la elaboración de pan (harina azúcar y manteca) que se constituye en capital de arranque de su propia panificadora. El crédito solicitado irá destinado a la construcción de un horno de ladrillo que será construido en su domicilio, elaborar su propio producto y así poder independizarse Es la primera vez que recurre a un préstamo, sin embargo el estudio socioeconómico muestra que pueden mejorar sus ingresos y cubrir el préstamo.

loans.use: Investment capital.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty has 3 years of experience running her business. She began to be interested in selling when she helped a friend who sold products in the country. Little by little, Betty started to like this sort of business. So, she asked for a loan, and started her own business. Now on the weekends she goes with a group of other people to sell. She works from 8 until 7. Betty wants a loan so that she can invest in different products that she does not currently sell, like sandwich makers, blenders, irons, and radios. Betty is a single mother of 2. Both children and her granddaughter live with her. One child was born mentally challenged. Betty receives monthly payments from the children's father. She wants to be able to sell from her home so that she can stop traveling and stay with her children. Slowly, she has been able to continue to build her cement home.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Betty tiene una experiencia de 3 años con su negocio. Actividad que la inicio por medio de una amiga con la que trabajaba viajando a los campos. Poco a poco le fue gustando el negocio y decide prestarle un dinero a ella y forma su propio capital de trabajo. Ahora ella viaja junto con otras personas los fines de semana en la que realiza sus ventas. Su horario de trabajo es desde las 8 p.m. hasta las 7 a.m.

Betty desea el crédito para poder invertir en otra clase de artículos que no tiene a la venta. Como lo son sanducheras, licuadoras, planchas, radios.

Betty es madre soltera. Tiene 2 hijos y una nieta que vive con ella. De sus hijos uno es especial ya que nació con retraso mental. Recibe la ayuda del padre de sus hijos mensualmente. Su deseo es poder tener un propio local en su domicilio para no tener que estar viajando y más que todo para quedar al cuidado de sus hijos. Poco a poco ella ha logrado ir terminando su casita de cemento.

loans.use: Betty wants a loan so that she can invest in other items that she is not currently selling, such as sandwich makers, blenders, irons, and radios.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana has 8 years of experience in her business. She learned about this type of business while working with her mother. She was self-motived in starting her business. She began to sell right outside her home and was pleased with the results. This has motived her to continue in this endeavor but in another location. Right now she sells from a market near her home. She works every day from 5 am to 1 pm. Her children help customers as well. From her home, Ana also sells food and has the help of her children when she is working at the market. Ana wants a loan so that she can buy utensils for her business and be able to supply her store, which lacks adequate funding, with more products. Ana is a single mother of 4. All of them go to school and help her with the business in their free time. The children's father helps meet their needs. Even though Ana and the children's father are separated, they are on good terms. Ana hopes to provide her business with more items and use the resulting higher revenue to help her son buy a computer which he needs for the major he is pursuing in college.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

Ana tiene una experiencia de 8 años en el negocio. Se decidió por iniciativa propia ya que ella conocía del mismo por que trabajaba con su mama. Comienza a vender afuera de su domicilio y le fue muy bien. Lo que la motiva a seguir con el mismo pero en otro lugar. Al momento ella vende en un mercado cerca de su domicilio. Trabaja todos los días de la semana desde las 5 a.m. hasta las 1 p.m. Sus hijos la ayudan en la atención de los clientes. Además de su venta de comida ella también posee una tienda en su domicilio la que la administran sus hijos cuando ella esta en el mercado.

Ana desea el crédito para poder comprar utensilios para su negocio y también poder surtir su tienda la que esta un poco baja de capital. /p>

Ana es madre soltera. Tiene 4 hijos. Todos estudian y en sus ratos libres le apoyan a ella con el negocio. El padre de sus hijos le ayuda en lo que ellos necesitan. A pesar de la separación llevan una buena relación. Su deseo es poder surtir su negocio y con su ganancia poder ayudar a su hijo en la compra de una computadora ya que la necesita por la carrera que esta siguiendo en la universidad.

loans.use: Ana wants a loan so that she can buy utensils for her business and to stock her store, which lacks adequate funding.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.en:
Ms Manuela and her husband, Jose, live on the outskirts of the city of Guachochi in the region of the Sierra Tarahumara. They have two children who attend school. Jose is a musician and works various parties. Their income is very inconsistent due to Jose’s vocation; thus, approximately one year ago Manuela decided to start a small grocery store business with the aim of obtaining an additional income and of helping with her children’s expenses. At the start of her business she began supplying merchandise with her husband’s income and little by little she has increased her sales. Her business is a family endeavor: she manages the business and her children, when available, help her.

She seeks a loan of 475 dollars to supply merchandise to her business now that her sales have increased. She intends to pay back the loan within 6-12 months. Your support of Manuela and her family is greatly appreciated.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Manuela y su esposo Don José viven a las afueras de la ciudad de Guachochi en la región de la Sierra Tarahumara, ellos tienen dos hijos los cuales asisten a la escuela. Don José es músico y trabaja tocando en fiestas, es por eso que sus ingresos son muy variables, debido a ello hace un año aproximadamente Doña Manuela decidió iniciar su pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes, con la finalidad de obtener un ingreso adicional y poder ayudarse con los gastos de sus hijos. Al principio de su negocio empezó a surtir de mercancía con los ingresos de su esposo y poco a poco ha ido incrementando sus ventas. Su negocio es familiar, ella esta al frente del mismo y sus hijos le ayudan cuando tienen tiempo.

Ella esta solicitando un préstamo por $ 475 USD para surtir de mercancía su negocio, ya que sus ventas se han incrementado últimamente, y piensa pagarlo en un plazo de 6-12 meses. Apoya a Doña Manuela y ella y su familia te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: To purchase consumables

loans.name: Maria De La Luz

texts.en:
Ms Luz learned how to sew when she was very young—she would watch her older sister, who dedicated herself to this trade. Ms Luz is married; her husband is a driver and he has always supported her and her business. Luz started her business with the idea of offering a better future to her children of 9 and 17 years of age; they both attend school, the younger one in primary school and the older female sibling in preparatory school.

Currently, the Luz’s business requires work capital because the cold temperatures of the last couple of months have undercapitalized the city; the winter is hard and decreases the economy considerably. Luz’s business employs three women, also mothers. She seeks a loan of 925 dollars to buy premium material and enable her to fulfill her customer’s requests. She intends to pay back the loan within 6-12 months.

She wants her business to continue growing so that she can support her daughter’s professional studies, which are fast approaching their start. With this loan, you are participating in and supporting the strengthening of Luz’s business, as well as contributing to the education of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Luz aprendió el oficio de costurera desde que era muy pequeña, ya que veía a su hermana mayor que se dedicaba a esta actividad. Ella esta casada, su esposo es transportista y siempre la ha motivado con su negocio.
